The SECOND SECRETARY is trying to be annoyed. Outside the sun is shining, it is early spring and the fi leaves are appearing on the trees. The door opens and BABY-FACE FITZROY puts his head round

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: [[Excuse me, sir, I-]] [I say ...]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: [[Ah, Mr Fitzroy, I was just about  to summon you. Come in.]] [Oh, Baby- Face, I want you a moment.]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Apprehensively) [[Yes, sir.]] [What is it?  Those  nursing home accounts?]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He comes in, revealing that he is beautifully dressed for tennis and even has his racket in his hand. The SECRETARY has looked at the bill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: [Yes.] Will you kindly explain [[,Mr  Fitzroy,]] what the deuce this item  means? Forty[[-two]] packs of playing  cards!! It's enough for the Casino  at Monte Carlo!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: [[Yes, sir]] [I know]. I spoke to  Miss Hunter - she says [[the evenings  were so long - ]] there's nothing  [[much]] [else] to do at Stolpchensee  in winter -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Having made his  protest, subsides) Very well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He ticks the item and goes on down the list. He looks up for the first time sees BABY-FACE in his spotless flannel college scarf and Harrow blazer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: [[Well, Fitzroy, what's all this?]]  [Don't you ever do any work?]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: [[Tennis, sir.]] First time this  year- if you can spare me, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hm! Well, don't catch cold! (Looks at bill.) These nursing homes are an expensive  business. Is Miss Hunter returning  to England?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As far as I know, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But not at our expense, I hope?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: [[Oh,]] [Good heavens] no, sir. She  was going anyway [[you remember]].

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Grunts, then suddenly) Well, so was Candy for that matter!  Eh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir, he had a return ticket but  it's expired.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Sigh) Very well. Buy him a new one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: [[(BABY-FACE is going, when the SECOND SECRETARY stops hi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr Fitzroy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir?]]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: [[Have]] [And get] Candy [to] give  you that [[time-expired]] [old]  ticket. We'll [[try and]] claim a  refund [[from]] [at] Cooks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Interior: Nursing Home

dialogues.speaker: CLIVE'S ROOM
dialogues.text: CLIVE and EDITH are packing. The window is half open to the garden. The sun is shining but the stove is still burning for it is cold out of the  rays of the sun.  EDITH is very quiet and subdued, notice so to anyone but CLIVE, who is whistling noisily. His  moustache is coming on nicely although it does not yet hi the scar. Each time he comes within range of the mirror,  CLIVE takes an approving look at the new moustache.   EDITH is just packing some handkerchiefs when CLIVE stops her and takes them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Half a mo'! Those belong to Theo.  Put them with the alarm-clock. (EDITH does so.) How's your own packing going? (Looks at watch.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (She finds it difficult  to speak) Not far.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you'd better hurry up then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ([Tearful]) I'll be all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be so sure. We've only got  half an hour if we are going to call  at the Embassy first. I can manage  here. Come on, stop mooning about!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Tearfully and angrily) I'm not mooning about!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keep your hair on! (He stares.) I say, old girl, what's up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns away. He revolves round her with a bewildered l peers in her face. She looks back at him. She is crying. CLIVE is frightfully taken aback and quite helpless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edith! I say - Edith! What's the  matter? It's not because I didn't  call for you yesterday, is it? You  know В— Frau von Kalteneck left last  night for the South.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Sobbing) Did she?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you knew she was going!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd forgotten...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't help it if you don't like  horses, can I?  We went to see her  racing-stables - she has some fine  [[horses]] [beasts] but they're too  fat. Edith! do stop crying! Suppose  somebody comes in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (With feminine logic) Nobody will come in...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look!  I promise to take you out the  first night we're back in London!   [[We'll go to]] 'Her Majesty's'  [Theatre] - 'The Last of the Dandies' -  they say it's [an] awfully good  [show].

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Still sobbing) - I saw - the paper said -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What paper? What do you mean? Is  that what's making you cry?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Shakes her head) - the paper said - there's a new  play at 'Her Majesty's Theatre' -  called 'Ulysses' - !

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door opens and somebody does come in: NURSE KONIG.  S has an armful of books.  EDITH quickly turns her back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (To CLIVE) Oberleutnant Kretschmar-Schuldorff  returns your books, Mr Candy. He is  on his way to see you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Moving at once) I must hurry!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'd better! We'll meet in the hall!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. (She has gone.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLIVE looks after her with a frown for a moment. Then his face clears. Girls are strange and anyway there will be l of time to find out what's wrong. He looks ruefully at th books, which are all German editions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What am I going to do with them? I  don't read German.  Miss Hunter got  them for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can present them to our library.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clever Nurse Erna. (The [[Brunhilde]]  [Mignon] Aria is  whistled outside.) So Clive Candy's name will always  live in a corner at Stolpchensee! (Changes tone.) But I must write my name in them. (He hears the whistle.) Hullo, Theo!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THEO appears at the window. During the first part of the  scene CLIVE is writing his name in the books.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (He speaks a hybrid  language now, like

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kann ich come in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Certainly, [come in] my old horse. (As THEO climbs  through.) My old steeplechaser!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THEO'S scar is visible on his forehead. Otherwise he is a right. THEO looks round.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wo ist Edith?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Packing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Surprised) Packing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, of course! Und Sie? How much  longer Sie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eine week В— or two. (Makes sign with  fingers.) Clive!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edith come here! Translate for us!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can translate -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Shakes his head) Nicht das! Very important.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shall I fetch Miss Hunter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now look here, don't disturb her,  she'll never be ready! (To THEO) Ich mussen call at Embassy, old man -  get my ticket nach London.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Insists, to NURSE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: [Ja.] Please!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NURSE KONIG leaves the room. CLIVE does not understand at all. He shrugs despairingly points to the drinks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drink?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: [Nein.] Not now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right. What the blazes is up  with everybody?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Very sincerely) Clive! You and I friends. Yes or no?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course we're friends!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: [[Very sorry, but you and I]] [We]  must duel again!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Stares) Where's your dictionary, old chap?  You must have got two pages stuck  together!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Smiling) I В— love - your - (He tries to find the  word 'fiancee' but  can't.) Teufel! Your - Miss Hunter В—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Can't believe his  ears) Say that again!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I - love - your - Miss Hunter!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're cuckoo!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Still smiling) [[No]] [No, ich nein 'cuckoo'], you  'cuckoo'! Because Miss Hunter love  me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLIVE stares. Gets up. Examines THEO again.  THEO nods. C suddenly smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Congratulations! (He grabs THEO'S hand.) When did it happen? Why don't I know  about it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Still smiling) No duel?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Duel? I- (Thumps chest.) Ich!  Fight anyone who tries, to  stop it! Now will you have a drink?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Double drink!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Pouring) But you know, old man, Edith was  never my fiancee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fiancee! The word I not find!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Handing drink) Not my fiancee! ( (Chinks glasses.) Lovely girl! Sweet girl! (They drink.) But not my fiancee!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: [[(Thoughtfully) So?]] [Bottoms up!]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door opens. NURSE KONIG comes in. She evidently knows has guessed the whole situation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have a drink, Nurse Konig! Where's  the fiancee?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He bows to THEO, who bows back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She can't come down -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then we go up. Come on, Theo!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They start for the door. Stop with the same idea. Look at each other, turn, pick up bottles and glasses and hurry o

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Interior: Nursing Home

dialogues.speaker: EDITH'S ROOM
dialogues.text: EDITH looks like a young woman waitingto have her mind ma up for her. She is not packing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edith!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come in.]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door flies open and she starts round as THEO and CLIV invade the room, beaming and carrying bottles and glasses One glance at their faces shows her that the ice has been broken.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edith, my child! I feel like a proud  father!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Rather faintly) Do you, Clive?  Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to give you away, don't I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How did you find out?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Theo told me in fluent Double Dutch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Proudly) I told. (To EDITH) Das einzige Wott ich konnte nicht  finden war 'fiancee'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They all dissolve in laughter.  CLIVE hands round drinks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A toast! This to the happiness of my  fiancee who was never my fiancee and  of the man who tried to kill me before  he was introduced to me.  Prosit!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They all drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Puts down glass) May I kiss the bride?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why ask? I have [did] not ask!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EDITH looks at CLIVE. He steps swiftly forward and takes in his arms for the first and last time. They kiss each other. It is an important moment. It is a  brotherly and sisterly kiss; but for a fraction of a seco both close their eyes. When CLIVE'S eyes are open his whole expression has chang Suddenly he has realized the truth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Low voice) Goodbye, Clive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodbye, Edith - old girl. I hope  we'll meet again sometime -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure we shall -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLIVE turns to THEO and takes his hand. He still holds  EDITH'S. He is just a little drunk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now look here, you son of a gun! You  won't understand a word of what I'm  going to say - but I came to Berlin  to find a rat and found two of the  grandest people I ever met. [[I'm a  little bit drunk.]] I leave to you,  you Prussian stiff-neck, this girl  in trust; and if you don't take care  of her I'll raise the whole of England  against you! The Navy will steam up  your stinking Stolpchensee!  I shall  lead the Army down Unter den Linden!  and we'll -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Laughing) Stop! Kamerad!]]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLIVE stops, stares, finishes his drink and pours out ano one for himself and THEO. THEO has an inkling of how the land lies. He looks gaily tenderly at them both before he speaks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (To CLIVE) [Clive,] my English is not very much.  But my friendship for you is very  much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I'm sorry that I have to refuse  your invitation to go to'Her Majesty's  Theatre'.]]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Interior: War Office, Colonel Betteridge's Office

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Door of Betteridge's office as in Sequences 21-23

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope it's taught you a damn good  lesson, Candy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now inside the office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trouble with you young fellows is  you always want to go changing  everything. And what's the result?  You spend all your leave in a nursing  home full of foreigners. You cost  the Treasury a lot of money. You  make the Foreign Office very cross,  yes very cross. And what do you get  for it?  Your beauty's spoilt. You  weren't any fashion plate before.  I'd be surprised if any woman would  look twice at you now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So would I, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When you were here in January, I  told you very clearly it was not  your concern. It was an Embassy job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, sir, I suppose I thought I'd  take a chance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A chance? A chance?  You can't afford  to take a chance with your career,  my boy. You are in the Army as a  career, aren't you, not for five  minutes? You were putting up a pretty  good show. You go barging in on this  nonsense and you come pretty near to  getting yourself kicked out. You  don't want to get yourself kicked  out, do you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, let me tell you one thing.  Don't bother your head with things  you don't understand and you won't  go far wrong. Don't go off at half- cock. Keep cool. Keep your mouth  shut. And avoid politicians like the  plague. That's the way to get on in  the Army.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Moving round the  desk) Care to dine at my club tonight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, sir, I'm taking someone to  the theatre.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pretty?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I haven't met her yet, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're still a bit cracked, my boy.  Well, I hope you improve as you get  older. And cheer up, my boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Interior: Her Majesty's Theatre

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The new musical play Ulysses by Stephen Phillips is being performed. The scene is Olympus, the Council of the Gods. Zeus despa Hermes to earth with orders to Calypso to free the ship o Ulysses. Background of thunder, etc. The curtain descends with a crashing climax from the orchestra and the effects man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Father, whose oath in hollow Hell is  heard; Whose act is lightning after  thunder-word; A boon! a boon! - that  I compassion find  For one, the most unhappy of mankind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How is he named?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ulysses. He who planned To take the  towered city of Troy-land.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What wouldst thou?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This! That he at the last may view  the smoke of his own fire c ruling  blue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where bides the man?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Calypso this long while Detains him  in her languorous ocean-isle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Father of gods, this man has stricken  blind my dear son Polyphemus, and  with wind, With roaring waves, by me  let him be hurled From sea to sea  and dashed about the world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peace, children, and from your shrill  reviling cease!  Hermes, command  Calypso to release Ulysses and to  waft him over seas.  Ulysses shall  return.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cloud-gatherer, stay!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yet canst you work in mischief on  the way   , Yet ere he touch at last  his native shore, Ulysses must abide  one labour more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HOPPY and SYBIL arrive late in their box at this point.]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (In a box) Where's the bar?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darling, do control yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I say, there's old Suggie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really, darling?  Where?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suggie ... Suggie ... Suggie. (Getting louder, until  he attracts a scowl  from one of the  actors.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLIVE, at last, responds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Whispers) Who is the girl with Clive, darling?  Do you know her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (He seems to be  enjoying a secret  joke) As a matter of fact I do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, darling [who is she]?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Still enjoying his  joke) I believe he met her sister in Berlin -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darling, why all this mystery? Who  is she?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My niece's governess - a Miss Hunter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Whispers to his  companion) [[What is the world coming to?]]  [Wonders will never cease.]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What, Lieutenant Candy?]]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Indicating girl with  Hoppy) Sybil Gilpin out without her mother!  [And with Hoppy too.]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, didn't you know [,Mr Candy]?  They are married!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hoppy! Sybil!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Over a month [ago. The family were  quite taken by surprise. It was very  romantic and sudden. They met here  in this very theatre.]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: [[And to think that I sent Hoppy to  take my place - ]] [I know,] I seem  to be a born matchmaker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Interior: 33 Cadogan Place

dialogues.speaker: HALL
dialogues.text: A brisk tattoo with the front door knocker is bringing PE to the door with dignified haste. PEBBLE is the Head  Parlourmaid of Lady Margaret Hamilton's exclusively femal establishment. PEBBLE opens the door on the chain. CLIVE is outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: [[Good evening]] [Hello], Pebble!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Master Clive!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She half closes the door, slips the chain and opens it wi CLIVE steps in. They talk in low tones as she closes the  door and takes his things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your Aunt is asleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: [[Never mind, Pebble. Don't wake  her.]] [All right, don't disturb  her.] I didn't feel like going to  the Club tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not sick, Master Clive?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I say, Pebble, how did you feel when  you buried Mr Pebble?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It wasn't so bad at the time, Master  Clive, there was so much to do. It  was after that it got bad, if you  understand me. (CLIVE nods gloomily.) I hope you haven't come from a  burying, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. From the theatre. But it was the  same thing, in a way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was it a sad play?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the contrary. It was a musical  play. Is the bed in my Den made up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, sir, but it won't take a minute  if you don't mind sleeping in  blankets. There isn't time to air  the sheets. Lady Margaret has made  some changes, Master Clive, you'll  see when В—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pebble! What is going on there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: [[CLIVE signs to PEBBLE not to give him away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing, Lady Margaret.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a liar, Pebble!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LADY MARGARET HAMILTON appears on the landing, carrying a small brass oil-lamp. She is in her night attire.  She is brusque in conversation as in letter-writing.  She sees C

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clive!  How dare you come waking up  the whole neighbourhood at this hour  of the night. Go to your club!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLIVE smiles and comes running up the stairs to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right. I'm going.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He scoops his aunt up in his arms before she realizes his intention. PEBBLE passes up the stairs smiling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you hear me, nephew? Go to your  club!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very well. Let's go!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He starts down stairs at a great rate, carrying her as if she were a feather.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Highly enjoying it) Put me down, you fool!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I can stay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I suppose so, since there's no man  here to throw you out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLIVE at once runs upstairs and puts his aunt down on the landing again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How are you, Aunt Margaret?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You may give me a kiss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She offers her cheek. He gives her a big hug. She is not displeased. She examines him.]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Interior: 33 Cadogan Place

dialogues.speaker: CLIVE'S DEN
dialogues.text: It contains all the personal belongings which he really  cherishes.  It's a sportsman's room. He is a keen fisherm and there is a gun-cupboard in one corner. There are a nu of athletic cups and shields. Prominent on the wall are half a dozen or so heads of ani which Clive has shot in South Africa.  CLIVE and AUNT MARGARET enter the Den.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Am I staying?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I suppose so, since there's no man  here to throw you out.]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I say? Who put up my South African  heads?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've no idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They don't look half bad, do they?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. [Pebble, do stop fussing like an  old hen and go to your bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good night, Master Clive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PEBBLE leaves.]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: [Now,] Even money that some  catastrophe has brought you here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Debts?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A woman?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not exactly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Explain!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I went to the theatre tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With a girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And pray why is she 'not exactly'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, it's nothing to do with her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps. [[Who was there?]] See anyone  you know?]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I saw Hoppy with Sybil Gilpin. They're  married!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Certainly. A very suitable match. He  has money, she has land. [And neither  of them has any brains.] You weren't  in love with her, surely?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With Sybil? Oh, no.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am glad [of that]. She has muscles  like a prizefighter and she[['s bound  to]] ['11] hit Hoppy one day. [[Come  along! I want to show you your Den.]]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Judicially) Hoppy could give her a couple of  stone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She will soon make that up, I assure  you! Who is this girl you took to  the theatre?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Miss Hunter. I met her sister in  Berlin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is she nice?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very. I mean the sister.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which sister?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The one that stayed in Berlin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (After a pause, during  which she surveys  him) [Then] the one in London is not so  nice, I take it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ([Pauses]) No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AUNT MARGARET now knows the whole story.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Suddenly she changes  her tone) Now [[look here]] [listen], Clive. I  have eighteen rooms here, a bone- idle staff eating their heads off,  and when you come home from South  Africa, you go straight to your Club.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. It's awful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: [[I had the walls cleared for your  heads. Now,]] I want you to remember:  wherever you go - whatever you do В—  you've [always] got a home here! And -  whatever you shoot В— there's [always]  room here for them. Look how much  room there is!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLIVE looks around the big cosy room. He looks gratefully his aunt [[and puts his arm round her shoulders]]. Both of them look up at the heads on the wall. [Clive casts a growing shadow on the wall.] We see the heads, each with its plate, bearing the date a place where the late owner came face to face with the Bri acquisitive instinct. Music starts to play.  The walls become covered with trop from all parts of the British Empire: Trophies: Rhinocero Onyx, Lion, Tiger, Indian Elephant, Sambhur, Tarpon, Mahs Crocodile; Places: British East Africa, Sudan, Rhodesia,  Mysore, Upper Burma, United Provinces, St Helena, Kashmir Ganges Delta;  Dates: 1903, 1905, 1906, 1907, 1910, 1912,1914.  After 19 the wall is blank. The camera shows the bare wall, then swings to show a new trophy. A German spiked helmet, covered in khaki cloth, o the type used in the Great War. The inevitable plate says simply: 'HUN.  FLANDERS, 1918.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The principal reason up to this point for making the pict in colour is because colour is more successful in evoking period which, although some time ago, is still fresh in t memories of many people. We can claim, of course, the pin >odies of the General's Staff in the Turkish Baths and th General's Red Tabs, but these, however attractive, are  decorations. Sights, sounds, but above all, colours, make the memories of a generation: more so in the case of the  period with which we have dealt. 1902 was the commencemen of the Edwardian era, full of charm, prosperity, spacious and leisure, to which it seemed there could never be an e Our next use of colour is in the first part of the 1918В— Sequence which we call for convenience, the 'Khaki Sequen After four years of senseless trench warfare, all the col and variety of Europe and its peoples had been reduced to uniform dull colour by day and to blackness by night. Kha was the colour of clothes, faces, official forms, everyth while the battle zone itself had been reduced to a consis as featureless and as sticky as porridge. By this deliber elimination of all colours except Khaki, we hope to point this contrast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exterior: Somewhere in Flanders

dialogues.speaker: A CROSS-ROAD
dialogues.text: It is dusk. It is not raining but it has been and it will again.  An Army staff car, 1918 vintage, is approaching a the road, once a pleasant avenue, now a dreary, cratered  embankment lined with splintered stumps. The continuous thunder of heavy guns sounds in the far  distance.  The car bumps to a stop at the cross-roads.  O the back seat sits COLONEL (Acting Brigadier} CLIVE CANDY He is now a man of forty-two, many ribbons on his chest. moustache is heavy but well cared for, he looks tired but full of energy and devotion to serve his country. He has map spread out on the seat beside him. His driver, [[MULLINS]] [MURDOCH], is also his batman. He about the GENERAL'S age; out since Mons. The landscape, the sky, the car, the men and their mud- plastered uniforms are all one pervasive scheme of khaki. The only Spots, of colour are the GENERAL'S Red Tabs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is Dead Cow Cross-roads, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GENERAL CANDY stands up on the back seat of the car and,  through his glasses, examines the landscape.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Mutters) The question is: whether that is the  Church with the double tower, or the  'Estaminet du Pont'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through his powerful glasses we see the featureless mass rubble at which he is looking. God knows what it is.  MUR sits fatalistically.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn it, Murdoch, you're supposed to  know the road!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know it at night, sir. In the  daytime it looks different.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CANDY snorts. MURDOCH suddenly sniffs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eh? Got a scent?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. (Sniffs again.) That's our road. I can smell the two  Jerries the Sappers planted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For'ard then!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harkaway, sir!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somewhere in Flanders

dialogues.speaker: EXTERIOR
dialogues.text: We see it in the last dull light of the fading day. The r has started again, a persistent drizzle. All distinguishi features of the Estaminet have either fallen down or fall in long ago. It is gradually vanishing into the mud and n cares.  MAJOR VAN ZIJL is waiting outside in the yard as GENERAL  CANDY'S car drives up. He has a lady's brown silk umbrell against the rain. He is a tough, lively South African of  thirty-four, a veteran of the Boer War. He squelches over the duckboards to the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Glad to see you, sir. I've got another  umbrella for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He produces. The GENERAL accepts it gratefully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've a marvellous eye for loot,  Van Zijl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Learnt from the English in the Boer  War, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Chuckles) Where d'you get 'em?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Off JerriesВ—eleven of them-brought  in an hour ago.  Lord knows where  they stole them, they were using  them for camouflage against aircraft.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: While talking they have left the car, crossed the duckboa and gone into the Estaminet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Interior: Estaminet du Pont

dialogues.speaker: BAR
dialogues.text: The room is now the Outer Office of Battalion H.Q. MAJOR ZIJL is in command. Can see vaguely that once this was a pleasant little cafe just as with some filthy old tramp it is not beyond conje that he was once a young, attractive man. The contrast is great. The room is crowded. Clerks are working and there is a  telephone exchange. Several officers around. As GENERAL CANDY and MAJOR VAN ZIJL enter, everybody stan to attention.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Saluting) Good evening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He glances round, starts towards the Inner Office, then s and speaks to VAN ZIJL.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can we get through to the R.T.O. in  Dupuis-sur-something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dupuis-sur-Crois. The Yanks are down  there. How about it, Paddy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Fraid the lines broke between us  and 'Mile 14', sir. We can send a  runner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What message, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell him to hold a place on the leave- train. When can I leave here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not before dark. They're plastering  the road between 17 and 19 with  shrapnel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right. Will someone look after  Murdoch?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobby! Paddy, get that runner away!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If any of you have got an important  letter or message home, I'll take  it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, sir!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLIVE goes across. VAN ZIJL follows, calling over his  shoulder:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paddy! I'll [[tackle]] [see] the  prisoners again presently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Interior: Estaminet du Pont

dialogues.speaker: KITCHEN
dialogues.text: This was once the large kitchen and chief living room of cafe's owner. You would scarcely guess it now. Its presen function is office of the Battalion Commander.   The GENERAL has heard VAN ZIJL'S last remark. He goes to fire and stands in front of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are these prisoners?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ulans. The Second Regiment. That's  all I've got out of them so far.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Second Regiment of Ulans? I'd  like to question them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Secretly unwilling) Certainly, sir. (Goes to passage,  yells.) Paddy!  Bring in the prisoners.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any officer with them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No such luck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where did you nab them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Floating down the river early this  morning. I had a boom across and  netted them like salmon. They had a  hundred pounds of dynamite with 'em.   My guess is they were after the new  pontoon-bridge below St Mangy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How the blazes did they get to know  about that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They took one of our patrols prisoner  day before yesterday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Stares) Are you suggesting our fellows talked?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Germans know how to make them  talk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A little pause follows.  CLIVE is thinking, a fact betray by a heavy frown and an occasional 'Hm!' He shakes his head as if unwilling to believe something. ZIJL watches him, half affectionately. The slim, dark Sou African is a contrast to the solid Englishman. He produce paper from his pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Finally speaking) [Well if they are,] They're cracking,  my dear chap. It's a sure sign. Nobody  starts to fight foul until he sees  he can't win any other way. I quite  believe Hindenburg, who I hear said  the other day that until now ' Germany  has used her arms with honour - (After a slight pause.) I admit he said nothing about her  legs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VAN ZIJL has unfolded the paper, which is printed in Germ

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This bears you out, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was on one of the prisoners.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me see it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's in German.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh! Well, read it.]]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door opens and the eleven German prisoners march down the passage and into the room under an escort with fixed  bayonets. The prisoners have none of the colourful appear of the Ulans of 1902. All the same they are defiant altho not arrogant, as Nazi prisoners would be. They remain gra and serious all through the scene. Outside it is almost d and the rain has got heavier. The wind has got up. [[When the prisoners come in an Orderly brings in three or four  candles stuck in bottles and one oil-lamp with a cracked smoky chimney and no shade. Another Orderly blacks out th windows. The escort lines the prisoners up against the wa During all this action, VAN ZIJL reads aloud from the Ger paper to the GENERAL.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's an appeal from the 'Erster  General Quartier-Meister', from old  man Ludendorff himself, to his loyal  troops. It starts: 'Soldiers, stand  fast or Germany will lie in the dust.  Should the enemy discover that our  Mannzucht - (He searches for the  word) Our morale is broken, all is lost,  you will have fought and suffered in  vain and the Homeland will hear the  tramp of the invader.' What do you  think of that, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Grim smile) What else?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is watching the prisoners as he listens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Reads) 'Have you heard the British say that  Germany has fallen? Is this to be?  Nein und abermals nein! (He mocks the style.) Thus far they have seen only German  faces, shall they now see only our  backs? Stand, or the Fatherland is  doomed and you with her!'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Thoughtfully) There's a rumour that the Kaiser  abdicated yesterday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Again, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLIVE smiles and walks over to the line of prisoners. The have heard VAN ZIJL reading Ludendorff's appeal but they  have given no sign of having understood.] GENERAL CANDY walks down the line, examining each prisone closely. He stops and walks back to a commanding position front of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do any of you know Oberst Kretschmar- Schuldorff?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't play deaf! He was an Oberst in  your Regiment the last time I heard  of him - Oberst Kretschmar-Schuldorff,  Second Regiment of Ulans!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which of you can speak English?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No answer. VAN ZIJL bursts out, addressing one of them:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You! You spoke English an hour ago!  Answer the General!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do speak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah! Now [[I want to tell you  something]] [listen to me]. We don't use the same methods that I  hear you use on your prisoners. But  I assure you that we have means to  get what we want. (Pause.) What was this explosive found on you  intended for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Blusters) Don't lie!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VAN ZIJL'S face as he listens is a study.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You took three of our men prisoner  two days ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then how did you know about the  bridge?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know nothing about a bridge...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Bellows) Then why were you carrying dynamite?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No answer. GENERAL CANDY draws a long breath.  Fortunatel PADDY comes in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right to go now, sir. Your car's  waiting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Won't you stay for dinner, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What have you got?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Macaroni. We found it in the cellar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beastly stuff!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the usual corned-horse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks. I'll take my chance in Dupuis.  Pity I've got to go. I'd like another  [[try]] [shot] at those prisoners.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Shepherding him) I've got the idea, sir. I'll tackle  them for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right! Make your report to Brigade.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very good, sir.]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somewhere in Flanders

dialogues.speaker: EXTERIOR
dialogues.text: [[Very dark,]] wind and rain. The officers are seeing GEN CANDY off. [[All hold ladies' umbrellas over their heads carry electric torches.]]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dirty night! I prefer Natal to  Flanders! Don't you, Van Zijl?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have seen nights like this on  Commando, General, even in Natal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Laughs) Good luck with your new enemy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodbye, sir. Let's hope the show's  over by the time you're back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not much chance of that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know the road, driver?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blindfold, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He only lost his way three times  coming here!  Carry on, Murdoch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The car drives away. [[The others look after him, smiling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good old Sugar Candy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did he get anything out of the  prisoners?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not a sausage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shall I lock 'em up again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, no. Now we put the screws on!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Didn't you this afternoon, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, my lad. Not with Sugar Candy  coming. He has a tender heart. Now,  listen! Take four men ...]]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Interior: Estaminet du font

dialogues.speaker: KITCHEN
dialogues.text: [[The prisoners stolidly wait the return of the officers. Their guards survey them impartially.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When's the war going to end, Jerry?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who knows?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Your Kaiser has a  rough idea.]])

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAJOR VAN ZIJL [[comes in.  He]] goes straight up to the  English-speaking prisoner who looks at him in a very diff way than he looked at GENERAL CANDY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Crisply]) [Now] Listen! I am in command here  now and I know how to deal with you  scum. I am not a simple English  gentleman but a simple South African  and I assure you that I have means  to get what I want. ( (His paraphrase is  deliberate and he is  obviously thinking  in the 'taal'.) What was the dynamite for? How many  of you got away? What happened to  the three men you took prisoners?  Thirty seconds to reply! [[ (Pause.) If you do not understand the questions  I have a squad of interpreters  outside, whom you will understand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Outside in the yard we hear the tramp of men.  PADDY'S vo shouts: 'Squad! Halt! Order-Arms!' There is a crash as th ground arms on the stones. VAN ZIJL sits down at his desk. He looks at the men in fr of him, playing with a sjambok which lies on the desk.  H glances at his watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right!  Cooper!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The three men nearest the door. Take  them out and shoot them! Lieutenant  Casey is in command of the firing  squad!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PRIVATE COOPER stares.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jump to it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir! (To the prisoners) Come on! You three!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They go out. The two remaining Tommies exchange uneasy lo So do the prisoners.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (To the PRISONER who  speaks English) Shall I repeat the questions?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PRISONER makes no answer: he is listening.  A command rin out: 'Fire!'  There is a volley, other ominous sounds.  Footsteps are heard leaving the yard and coming back to t kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Looks again at his  watch, then says to  the prisoners) Thirty seconds! Shall I repeat the  questions?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You cannot shoot us - there is an  international convention about  prisoners!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, you can speak English, too?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PRIVATE COOPER enters and grounds arms. He looks very gri Pause.]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right! The next three, Cooper!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Indicating the first  English-speaking

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can take the tall one. I've found  another interpreter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You there!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I protest!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Protest rejected.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The second three are hustled out. The five remaining men are really frightened. VAN ZIJL addresses them ruthlessly:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: International conventions! You think  they are useful on this side of the  line, don't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please - Herr Kommandant - I want to  speak to the others in German.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go ahead. You have-- (Glances at watch.) thirty seconds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Interior: Estaminet du Pont

dialogues.speaker: BAR
dialogues.text: The whole room is grinning at the first three prisoners w are standing by the porch. The door opens and PRIVATE COO ushers in the next bunch, just condemned to 'death'. At t sight of their comrades they are so surprised for a momen they can't even speak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somewhere in Flanders

dialogues.speaker: EXTERIOR
dialogues.text: The front door opens and a torch flashes a signal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's the signal, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right and for God's sake don't point  at me. Ready?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Suppressed laughs) Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Yells) FIRE!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A volley crashes out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Interior: Estaminet du Pont

dialogues.speaker: BAR
dialogues.text: COOPER grins cheerfully at the FIST PRISONER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll bet your pals are talking  nineteen to the dozen!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is against international Law...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you want to stand outside in the  rain?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then shut up!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exterior: Somewhere in Flanders

dialogues.speaker: FADE IN
dialogues.text: It is pitch dark. The rain has stopped for a moment. The  signal, which is at 'green', swings up to 'red'. We hear train receding in the distance. GENERAL CANDY'S car is waiting for the barriers to open. light of the headlamps shines on the mud-stained barriers They rise into the air. MURDOCH puts in the clutch but the delay has been fatal.  They are stuck in the deep mud. The wheels turn madly but get no grip. The GENERAL, a darker mass in the darkness,  shines his torch down on the wheels.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Shouts) Sentry!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Shouts) SENTRY! (To MURDOCH) There must be somebody there! Who  opened the gate? SENTRY!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Weary American voice) Every perishing car sticks in the  perishing mud, I'm not a perishing  service station!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Shouts) This is General Candy's car!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence. Then feet squelch towards them. CANDY flashes his torch o his wrist-watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 11.15. How far are we from Dupuis?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two kilometres, General

dialogues.text: (Ringing off) [[Well, General, that's rich.]] ([Cuts in.) What's that? What General? The hell  you say? Well, that's that.]

dialogues.text: (Has listened without  awe but active  interest to the  General's outburst,  as if at a play) Grub, sir?

dialogues.text: A - ? (Hehesitates.)

dialogues.text: [[Good. Well,]] show me the way,  will you [[- what's your name - er -  Lieutenant]]?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Grinning) Yes, sir. I've got cousins in  Westphalia. My father told me to  give 'em hell if I met up with them.  This way, sir.]]

dialogues.text: : I think I hear Armstrong coming  with the bathtub now.] (The two men  step out into the darkness. [[(The  two waiting soldiers are left alone.

dialogues.text: You can step on it, Armstrong. The  General's in a hurry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.text: She opens the gate and the General comes in.

dialogues.text: Merci, madame, [[je suis - je suis  mange - ]][... les Americains ...  j'ai mange ...]

dialogues.text: Oui-mange -

dialogues.speaker: REFECTORY
dialogues.text: The NUN and GENERAL CANDY arrive at the door. She opens i and they go in. The GENERAL stands astonished at what he sees. Part of th Refectory has been hit by a shell but it is still a noble hall. Long tables run down the huge room and nuns are wai at table. At the table are sitting nearly a hundred young nurses fresh from England, their bright uniforms and brig faces making the first patch of colour since the Khaki  sequence started. Most of the nurses look up as the GENERAL enters, then st at him, muddy and stained, as he stands at the top of the steps. He stares at their eager young faces. He feels sud drained of energy.  Meanwhile the NUN has fetched two women: the MOTHER SUPER of the Convent and the MATRON who is Transport Officer fo the nurses. [[The MATRON is Scottish.]]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bonsoir, Madame.]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bonsoir, mon General, on va vous  soigner.]]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: [Good evening,] General, you have  fallen on your feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Smiles) I was beginning to think so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have sixty-eight young, freshly- trained nurses straight from England  all dying to nurse someone. What's  the trouble?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Startled) Trouble, Matron?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The nun said you had eaten something -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She got it wrong - I want to eat.  I'm hungry!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh! (To MOTHER SUPERIOR  and NUN) C'estqu'il veut manger!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone smiles. The NUN titters. The MOTHER SUPERIOR and the MATRON have a hurried conference out of which the MAT emerges with an invitation. While they have talked, GENER CANDY looks down the crowded tables. He sees a girl. She is seated about halfway down the table. She has eaten and, like several of the nurses, has fallen asleep. CLIVE stares and stares. He knows that face and we know i too. The girl wears her hair differently, she is much you than Edith Hunter - but her face is very like Edith's. CL longs to see the colour of her eyes. [[The MATRON turns to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's all right, General, won't you  join us? We shall all be delighted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. (To MOTHER SUPERIOR) Merci, ma mere.]]

dialogues.text: (Smiles) Sois bienvenu, [[monfils]] [General. (To the NUN) II va rester avec nous.]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: [That's settled then. We should be  delighted to have you join us.] Have  you been in the front line?  I suppose  you have?  Before I got this job I  was with the Italians. I was lucky.  I came through Caporetto without a  scratch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Absently) Good heavens! What insect powder do  you use, Ma'am?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MATRON laughs heartily. As they pass the sleeping girl, CLIVE CANDY stops  involuntarily. Yes, the girl is strangely like Edith Hunt The MATRON is now at the head of the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (To the nurse next to  her) Move a bit, my dear - Sit down,  General. (To a NUN) Une assiette, s'il vous plait. (To CLIVE, who sits  down) We have macaroni.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Splendid! (He still can't take  his eyes off the  girl.)

dialogues.text: He addresses the MATRON.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Matron! Have you ever seen the Indian  Rope trick?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Surprised) No, General. Have you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLIVE nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pardon, Monsieur.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A plate is put before CLIVE loaded with macaroni. We see with CLIVE'S eyes the girl start to wake up. She s sleepily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It must be an incredible sight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Slowly) But I never [[met]] [heard  of] anybody who saw it unless he  [[first]] heard [[that]] he was going  to see it [first].

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I beg your pardon! I don't quite -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You hear about the thing. You hope  to see it - and you - see it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He eats his macaroni, never taking his eyes off the girl. The MATRON puts CLIVE'S vague way of talking down to  tiredness. The nurses around are all starting to get up a a general exodus starts towards the door. The girl stands with the others as the bench is pushed back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (To CLIVE) [Yes, General,] Will you excuse me?  [[I have to put my girls to bed. (She rises.]])

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Trying to see his  girl in a sudden  panic) [[Can you - who is that girl, please,  Matron? - The one who just got UP -  ]] [One moment, Matron, do you know  that girl over there?]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: [[Do you think you know her?]] I'm  afraid [[I can't tell you]] [I don't].  I only met them here at the station.  [[I must go, please excuse me.]] ([She rises.) Come along, everybody, come along.

dialogues.text: Fair.

dialogues.text: She's - fair. I couldn't see the  colour of her eyes. [Slim.]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry. It might be anyone. [[I was  asleep myself.]] Excuse me, General.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (A last attempt) Where do you come from tonight?   What detachment are you?

dialogues.text: The car is immobilized. The GENERAL is pacing impatiently and down.  MURDOCH, in an ostrich-like position, cleans t plugs. Finally the GENERAL stops and speaks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ((For the tenth time) How long now?

dialogues.text: (For the tenth time) Not long, sir.

dialogues.text: You've said that ten separate times.

dialogues.text: Well, hurry! The train leaves at  10.30.

dialogues.text: I know, sir.

dialogues.text: [[It's 9.30 now.]] I need extra time  in Ami-le-Bon. I'm going to G.H.Q.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: [[Don't talk]] [Stop talking] like  an infernal parrot, Murdoch. How do  you know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was told, sir.

dialogues.text: Who told you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Major van Zijl's batman, sir.

dialogues.text: What did he say?

dialogues.text: That you were up in the air, sir,  because the Major had got valuable  information from the Jerries - the  prisoners, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Controlling himself) Your misinformation, Murdoch, is  typical.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.text: The reason I am 'up in the air', as  your informant grotesquely describes  a very natural emotion, is because  this information was obtained by  intimidation!  By mental torture! By  firing squads!  By the same methods  that the Boches use!  If we are  fighting gangsters that is no reason  why we should behave like gangsters,  too.

dialogues.text: (Reads report) Bah! Four pages of 'confessions'!  Not worth the -

dialogues.text: You have no idea what I'm talking  about.

dialogues.text: No, sir.

dialogues.text: CLIVE suddenly remembers the girl of the previous night. is silent for a moment. Then he speaks in an entirely  different tone, which very few people have heard.

dialogues.text: Last night, Murdoch, I saw a girl -  a nurse straight from England...  I've never seen a more striking  resemblance...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She must have been a very common  type of girl, sir - the young lady  in Berlin, I mean.
