dialogues.text: She was a most uncommon - what the  devil d'you mean, Murdoch?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Stolidly) There was that girl in the film,  sir. You remember, you went nine  times. And there was that girl in  the group out of the Bystander! We  lost it in the big Push. And there's - (Without changing  tone) A despatch rider coming, sir!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A DESPATCH RIDER roars up and salutes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: General Candy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. (Signs pad.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Urgent message from Major van Zijl,  sir. Came over the wire from 'Mile  14'; they mended the line, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLIVE reads it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any answer, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. No answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The DESPATCH RIDER wheels and thunders away. MURDOCH look queerly at the GENERAL.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anything wrong, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLIVE shakes his head. They are alone in the immense  landscape, battered and trampled by four years of sensele stalemate war. CLIVE takes a flask from his pocket, unscr the little cup and fills it with brandy. He hands this to MURDOCH. CLIVE stands holding the flask.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Murdoch - the war is over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Germans have accepted the terms  of the Armistice.  Hostilities cease  at ten o'clock. (He looks at his watch.) [[It is now a quarter to ten.]] [It's  nearly that now.]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Struggles with words,  then gives up. They  drink.) God bless us, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Murdoch, may God bless us in  peace as He has in Victory.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns full of emotion and walks a step or two.  He turns and listens. Far away, born on the wind, there comes the sound of a mi cheering, louder and louder as every moment passes.  CLIVE turns to MURDOCH. He is exultant.]]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Murdoch! do you know what this means?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do, sir. Peace. We can go home.  Everybody can go home!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For me, Murdoch, it means more than  that. It means that Right is Might  after all. The Germans have shelled  hospitals, bombed open towns, sunk  neutral ships, used poison-gas - and  we won! Clean fighting, honest  soldiering have won! God bless you,  Murdoch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir!]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They both drink. [Sound of birdsong. Both look up to the sky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Interior: Yorkshire Cloth Mill

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A large and busy mill. Going closer to the machines, we s the last lengths of khaki cloth vanishing off the looms:  cloth, wool, cotton materials, all finishing.  In the dye vats the khaki dyes are emptied away: new beautiful dyes  appear: the looms are busy again. Gay patterns, bright tw are appearing. The first length of cloth off the looms is for a bridal gown.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INSERT: The Yorkshire Telegraph and Argus, June 6 1919.  Bradford.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After an interval of four years the first piece of white  brocade has come off the looms in the famous Mills of Mr. Christopher Wynne, head of the well-known West Riding fam The cloth is destined for the bridal gown of Miss Barbara Wynne, only daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Wynne, whose marriag to Brigadier-General Clive Candy, V.C., D.S.O. will short take place. General Candy is staying at The Hall.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exterior: The Hall

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beautiful, large garden. The great pile of 'The Hall' i the distance. The tiny figure of the HOUSEKEEPER on the  terrace. Faintly her voice is heard calling: 'Barbaraa! [Lunch is ready.] Miss Barbaraaaaaaaa!!'   In another part of the grounds, BARBARA WYNNEand CLIVE CA are talking together. A great sweep of country is visible beyond a great yew hedge. They have the copy of the Yorkshire Telegraph and Argus w them. BARBARA is, of course, the same girl whom we have seen in nurse's uniform in the Convent of the 'Crown of Thorns'. is dressed in what, in 1919, was considered a ravishing  creation: rather like a badly tied sack. CLIVE is in uniform. He is a full Brigadier now. He looks very strong and fit, far less than his forty-three years. Distantly we hear 'Barbaraaaa!'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh dear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Laughing]) Don't listen [to her]! (Accusingly.) Now!  [You listen to me.] There I  was asleep! You never saw me before -  you never [even] spoke to me then -  how could you be so sure?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I ask you a question first?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're wriggling! All right, fire  away!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How can you be so sure?  I'm twenty  years older than you - and I'm a  soldier. When other people are  thanking God the war is over, I am  going to the War Office to ask: Where  is another war where you can use me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Seriously) You asked me that once [before] and  I told you [[why]].

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm asking you again because I want  to hear it again [and again].

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He says this so charmingly that she has to answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm marrying you because I want to  join the Army and see the world. I'm  marrying you because I [[like seeing]]  [love watching] you play polo. I'm  marrying you for fifty reasons that  all mean that's how I imagined my  future husband!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLIVE looks at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Same here! That's how I imagined my  future wife!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BARBARA looks at him. It is one of the moments that come  seldom in life and extend indefinitely until some outside influence breaks them.  The beating of a big gong comes from the house. BARBARA s

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The gong is the final appeal. We  must go, darling. We have the Bishop  for lunch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope he's tender.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They start up the garden, hand in hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Interior: The Hall

dialogues.speaker: DINING ROOM
dialogues.text: A very fine room, full of good, solid stuff and good, sol people.  The BISHOP is making a little speech. MR and MRS WYNNE, BARBARA and CLIVE are listening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... and now [[let me]] [in conclusion,  I should like to] say a few words to  Brigadier-General Andy. We in the  Church Militant can admire the heroes  of the war. But in our hearts we are  men of peace. Therefore, I am glad  to have met you as I did for the  first time on a simple and heart- warming occasion [[and not]] [rather  than] at some military celebration.  When I first heard that a Brigadier- General of the British Army was  arranging a ball for the benefit of  those nurses from the West Riding  who took part in the four years'  struggle, I said [to myself]: There  is a man whose heart is in the right  place. (He refers to slip of  paper.) And I am glad to announce that one  result is that a total of ВЈ131.2.6  will be handed over to the War Nurses'  Benevolent Fund.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: During the BISHOP'S speech, CLIVE and BARBARA have glance at each other several times. CLIVE is guiltily rolling br pills. At the finish, after a little hesitation, he gets and stumbles into a speech replying. He starts to tell hi story as a good joke but as he sees it is falling flat, h gets more and more self-conscious, while as he speaks the faces of his listeners get more and more embarrassed. Onl BARBARA is unperturbed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: [[Your Grace]] [My Lord Bishop], I  want to make a confession. You see,  I first saw Barbara in Flanders on  the last night of the war. ((He glances at MRS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She was a nurse among seventy other  nurses - I never knew her name -but  I found out that most of the nurses  came from Yorkshire - the West Riding -  and of course she was a nurse -  [[well]] [so], I thought - Yorkshire's  a big place - [[Your Grace]] [My  Lord Bishop] - so, I thought, how  can I find a nurse in Yorkshire? You -  understand who I'm driving at - I  suppose - what I mean? -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a painful silence. The BISHOP does not rise to t occasion. But BARBARA does. She reaches for CLIVE'S hand holds it, smiling up at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I understand exactly what you mean,  darling!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exterior: 33 Cadogan Place

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A car of the period drives up and stops outside. It is an piled with luggage and dogs.  BARBARA is driving. CLIVE s beside her. They both look radiantly happy. She wears a  wedding ring. They both look up at the house; she Critically, he affectionately. It is the first time she s it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That window is the Den!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wrong. Next floor is the Den. That's  the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The window in question opens and a large Union Jack on th end of a pole is poked out of the window and socketed int its place. MURDOCH'S head appears behind it. He sees them below, ejaculates: 'It's them!' and disappears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is yon grey head Murdoch?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ((Nods) His idea of greeting the conquering  hero, I suppose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I shall like Murdoch - and I [[feel]]  [know] I shall like this house. Clive,  let [[it]] [the whole house] be our  Den, into which we can always crawl,  whether we return with rich spoils  or badly mauled from our rovings! Or  just to change our spots! [[Do  promise!]]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: [[(Looks at her I do.]] (He kisses her.) Aunt Margaret would have loved you  for that! (They go on talking  as idiotic lovers  do.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is a fine solid-looking property- (Mischievously) Like you. Clive, [[please don't ever]]  [you mustn't] change and don't ever  [[give up]] [leave] this house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No fear. Even if there is a second  Flood, this house shall stand on its  solid foundations and we'll have a  private lake in the basement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a promise. You stay just as  you are... till the floods come...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Raising his hand,  repeats) ... till the floods come...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Pointing into the  area) ... and this is a lake...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Repeats solemnly) ... and this is a lake!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MURDOCH appears at the entrance and stares in surprise at CLIVE standing there with his hand raised. He runs smartl down the steps. His manner, like his costume, is an Armis one: half-military, half-civil.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, Ma'am! - Mrs Candy - I was  [[up]] [at] the top [of the house] -  I wasn't expecting you so early,  sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you are Murdoch!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Madam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The first time I've ever heard him  answer anything but: 'Yes, sir!'  Well, Murdoch, this is [[my]] [the]  wife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They shake hands. MURDOCH has his own ideas of what a wif will want to know and he has his report all ready for her they all go into the house, carrying luggage, etc.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everything is under control, Ma'am.  I've had the telephone installed,  sir. (To BARBARA.) The agency has got a lot of cooks  for you to see, Ma'am, but I bought  plenty of vegetables and flour and  potatoes. ([They go in.]) And all the tradespeople have called  and will call again for [your orders] -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: [By this time they have entered the house.]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Interior: 33 Cadogan Place

dialogues.speaker: HALL
dialogues.text: BARBARA listens to MURDOCH with grave attention but CLIVE has no tender regard for his feelings. He interrupts him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's all right, Murdoch, but we're  not staying this time. Off tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Very disappointed) Yes, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paris for eight weeks. When we get  back we'll give a big party and put  our feet up for a bit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm [so] sorry, Murdoch. (She makes a friend.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Grins ruefully) [[I'm]] [We're] used to it [[Ma'am]]. ([[To CLIVE) I got your letters from the Club,  sir - they're on the little tray.]]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLIVE crosses to the table. MURDOCH continues to BARBARA:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told the porter that the Brigadier  wouldn't be using the Club so much  in future, Ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what did he say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MURDOCH hesitates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: [Go on, Murdoch,] I can bear it,  [[Murdoch]].

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: [[Yes, Ma'am.]] He said: They all  say that at first!' - Ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BARBARA laughs. MURDOCH smiles respectfully and withdraws with the dogs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I say, Barbara - ! (She crosses to him.) Here's an answer from the Prisoners  of War Committee -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have they found him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Very excited and  pleased) Yes. Theodor Kretschmar- Schuldorff,  Oberst, 2nd Regiment of Ulans of the  Guard.  That's him! Camp VII Hardwick  Hall, Derbyshire. Poor old Theo!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stares at the paper, pulling at his moustache. BARBARA knows what is going on in his mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darling!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLIVE looks up, worried. His face lights up as he sees he expression.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's postpone Paris... I'd love to  meet him -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exterior: Prisoners of War Camp

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: [Pan down from blue sky to barbed wire and on to: A notice, roughly printed by hand on a sheet of cardboard is nailed to a tree:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FГњR DEUTSCHE OFFIZIER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRANZ SCHUBERT:   UNVOLLENDETE SYMPHONIE [[LUDWIG v. BEETHOVEN:  FГњNFTE SYMPHONIE]]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DIRIGENT:  OBERLEUT. JOS. V. SCHONTHAAL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: While the notice is being read, we hear the tragically sw melody of the Second Movement of Schubert's 'Unfinished  Symphony'. The camera moves off the notice [[to the tree above. It h wide-spreading branches, all loaded with German officers, listening to the music. We see some of their faces. We se from their angle in the tree,]] [to a sentry on guard duty, and on to] the main audience the orchestra itself. All are German officers. The orches plays on a raised bank, a natural rostrum. The audience c the smooth lawns that run down to the river, which is cro by two bridges, with an island in the middle. There is a  Guard House on the island and the bridge is heavily wired with barbed wire above and below and English sentries are stationed on the bridge. The prisoners sit on benches or on the grass, many are  standing, all are listening intently to the music. There  must be 400 or 500 of them. The orchestra has about forty pieces. We see an ORDERLY coming towards the concert from the mai building. This is a fine old country house which has been taken over. It is now surrounded by huts and all kinds of administrative buildings. The main offices are in the hou itself. The ORDERLY carries a message-pad. He comes among the audience as discreetly as possible. [[He is obviously looking for someone and, as obviously, cannot spot him. H decides to ask one of the officers, who is leaning agains tree. The officer questioned looks around, then shakes hi head and taps the leg of another officer in the tree abov him. He whispers to him. The officer in the tree has a bi eye view. He spots the wanted man and the information is  passed on in whispers to the ORDERLY. The ORDERLY gingerl crosses through the audience. Nobody looks at him.]] He finds his man- OBERST KRETSCHMAR-SCHULDORFF - and touc him on the shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Message, sir, from the Commandant's  office.]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THEO turns to the ORDERLY. Of course, he, too, is sevente years older. He still bears the scar which he got in the  duel. The ORDERLY gives him the message-pad. THEO reads t message. He is surprised at its contents but, without any hesitation, he shakes his head very firmly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No answer.]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gives the message-pad back to the ORDERLY and turns on more to listen to the music. The ORDERLY is rather at a loss. After a moment's hesitat he starts all over again, emphasizing the importance of t message. THEO loses patience with him. He answers almost savagely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Louder than he had  meant to) No [answer]!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Heads turn. Voices go: 'Sh-sh-sh!' The ORDERLY beats a retreat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Interior: Prisoners of War Camp

dialogues.speaker: OFFICE OF COMMANDANT
dialogues.text: The tall french windows are open and the music can be hea in the distance. The Commandant, MAJOR DAVIES, is an elderly man and a bit a philosopher. CLIVE is in a new suit of tweeds with a regimental tie.  BARBARA wears a summer dress and hat which, in 1919 and i 1919 alone, was considered lovely. The ORDERLY knocks and enters - alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Drily) Well?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He said 'No [answer]'?  (He frowns  incredulously) What else?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He refused to come?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If that was the message, Ma'am. (He hands the pad TO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (BARBARA reads it, passes it to the  Major.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INSERT: message.  'Dear Theo, I am in the Commandant's Of I want to see you, "very much ". Clive Candy.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why is 'very much' [[in quotes]]  [printed like that]?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was a joke we had...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (To ORDERLY) Where was the Oberst?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listening to the [[orchestra]] [band],  sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, Higgins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ORDERLY goes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I [[thought, suddenly]] [was  thinking], how odd they are!  How  queer!  For years and years they are  writing and dreaming wonderful music  and [[wonderful]] [beautiful] poetry  and then [[suddenly]] [all of a  sudden] they start a war, shoot  innocent hostages, sink undefended  ships, bomb and destroy whole streets  in London, killing little children -  and then, dressed in the same  butcher's uniform, they sit down and  [[play]] [listen to] [[Beethoven]]  [Mendelssohn] and Schubert.  There's  something horrible about that, don't  you think so Clive?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Such abstractions are caviare to the GENERAL but he is  impressed by BARBARA'S speech.  He nods and grunts agreem

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hm - mm - [[something in that - good  deal in fact - ]]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is the first time there is something 'blimpish' in his manner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps I should have written in  German.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He understands English.  They have  all learnt English while they were  here.]]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The symphony ends.  Distant and prolonged applause.  CLIV stands up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Major Davies, would you mind if I  went down and had a try?  Perhaps it  was because of the music - there's  an interval now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: [[Certainly, you may]] [By all means]  try (Apologetically) but Mrs Candy  had better [[stay]]  [remain].

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BARBARA, who has risen, sits again.  She and MAJOR DAVIES understand each other.  CLIVE nods and moves to the windo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Half to himself) Can't understand it.  I've written  to him before the war and he has  written to me...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He vanishes out on the terrace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They stopped English lessons on the  11th of November.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On Armistice Day?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAJOR DAVIES nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exterior: Prisoner of War Camp

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the interval of the concert, the audience has broken u into groups, individuals are pacing up and down, some are smoking and talking. There is no loud chatter or laughter. The general effect serious, even solemn. Depression bangs over the stiff-nec assembly. CLIVE comes down from the house, walking quickl looking about him for THEO. He comes among the groups of officers. Nobody takes direc notice of him. The orchestra starts to tune up. People start to move bac to their places. CLIVE stops one group and addresses a senior officer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oberst Kretschmar-Schuldorff?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (After a sharp stare) [[Behind you.]] [Over there.]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He moves off. CLIVE whirls round.  He stands directly in between THEO and his place. THEO is advancing straight towards him, separated by two or three groups, also moving to their places. Seeing CLIVE, THEO stops. Not a muscle of his face or lig in his eyes betrays his thoughts. CLIVE, on the contrary, advances with a broad smile that  overflows his whole being. He is coming to his friend. He puts out his hand...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Theo!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THEO turns and walks away.  It is the greatest shock CLIVE has ever had. He stands  petrified, staring after his friend. THEO throws away his cigarette, treads on it and returns his place in the audience. Nearly everyone has settled  himself. CLIVE is left standing alone. [[The Conductor takes his place amid polite applause.]] [The music starts again.] CLIVE shakes his head as if he still can't believe what h happened to him. He looks ten years older. He turns and slowly walks away. THEO never looks after him. The orchestra plays the opening chords of [[Beethoven's F Symphony]] [Mendelssohn's Hebrides Overture].  CLIVE goes towards the house. He again shakes his head. For the seco time, there is something 'blimpish' in his behaviour. He stops and looks back, almost as if he is expected to s the figure of his friend, hastening after him.  But the l between him and the distant audience is empty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Interior: Prisoner of War Camp

dialogues.speaker: OFFICE OF THE COMMANDANT
dialogues.text: Distantly we hear the [[Fifth Symphony] Hebrides Overture which continues without a break. Since CLIVE left, tea has been served.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you find something rather  disturbing about these concerts - or  don't you mind?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not musical but I get used to  them. This is the 107th.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Smiles) You misunderstand me, Major - or do  you? (The MAJOR looks at  her.) What I mean is that we know that the  Germans in peacetime are a tidy law- loving people of poets, philosophers  and composers; and then -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLIVE appears at the window. He has recovered himself a  little. He comes in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it's true. I saw him and he  wouldn't speak to me. (He looks at BARBARA  and sits down.) I wouldn't have believed it possible.  He was as close as I am to you and  he turned away without saying a word.  You could have knocked me down with  a feather!  (BARBARA gives him  his tea. He stirs  it.) I kept on looking back, you know. I  couldn't believe he wasn't joking. (To MAJOR DAVIES) What on earth is wrong with him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The same thing as all the others.  They call it 'Ehre'. The literal  translation is 'Honour' but actually  I suppose it means 'Dignity'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What 'Dignity', what 'Honour'?  Who  has hurt his 'Ehre'? They lost, we  won. What of it. We've been defeated  too sometimes. Fortune of war!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Smiles) Good old sporting spirit. Always  time for a return match.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was taught to be a good loser. (He stirs his tea.) When are they going to be repatriated?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In six to eight weeks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What will you do then, Major Davies?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take a holiday, Mrs Candy - where  they don't speak German!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you're passing through London,  drop in!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When we're back from Paris, I'm making  Clive give a party for his friends.  If you can, do come.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. I'll try. I'd like to  talk to you about Germans, both of  you. You were going to say something  rather interesting just now -  something about peacetime and war?]]

dialogues.text: MAJOR DAVIES is just being helped out of his coat by MURD [[Behind him the hall clock is striking nine o'clock. F beyond we hear the unrestrained conviviality of an exclus male dinnerparty. CLIVE wears a dinner-jacket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, Davies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Candy. I hope your wife will  forgive me.]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Smiling) [[Awfully sorry, old man.]] [I'm  afraid] You haven't read the  invitation properly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Vaguely: glancing at  card) Ah, [[so it is,]] a Bachelor Party.  If I'd realized that your charming  wife wouldn't be here, [[I'd never  have hurried as I did]] [I shouldn't  have been in such a hurry].

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll find you something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks, I had dinner on the train.  I've come straight from Victoria.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On leave?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  Duty...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come and have a glass of port.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: While talking, they have walked towards the dining room w the hum of conversation has got louder. As they go in, th telephone in the hall rings. MURDOCH answers it. He has a special voice for answering the telephone, full of old-wo courtesy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is Brigadier-General Candy's  residence ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May I speak to the General?]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And who, may I ask, is speaking?...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is Oberst Kretschmar-Schuldorff,  speaking from Victoria Station. And  tell him I'm leaving tonight.]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you mind repeating the name,  sir...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Slowly) Theo Kretschmar-Schuldorff.]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He obviously hasn't got the name but is too polite to say so. He puts down the receiver and goes to get his master. We go close to the receiver. The man at the other end of wire is whistling - the Mignon Aria. CLIVE and MURDOCH co from the dining room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Couldn't he 'phone tomorrow? Where's  he speaking from?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Victoria Station, sir. He's leaving  tonight he said.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It sounded like Wretch-Bar Something,  sir -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kretschmar-Schuldorff!  Murdoch,  that brain of yours ought to be in a  bottle!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He snatches up the receiver and mouthpiece, he listens, g whistles in reply, laughs. He has quite forgotten the  impression he had been given at the prison camp, he is so pleased to be friendly to his friend again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Theo! [[You old son-of-a-gun! Where  are you?...  Victoria? What are you  doing there?]]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Victoria Station

dialogues.speaker: FIRST CLASS REFRESHMENT ROOM
dialogues.text: THEO is using the telephone behind the counter of the  refreshment bar.  [[Beyond him we see the busy bar and th whole big room, crammed with talkative and excited German officers.] THEO himself is in a very different humour tha when we have last seen him. He is going home. His uniform coat hangs over his shoulders. He talks good English now, with an accent. [[By him is LIEUTENANT CARTWRIGHT, the of in-charge.]]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: [Yes, it's me, Theo. How are you my  friend? Yes,] I'm going home - if  there is such a thing left in Germany.   [[How are you, my friend?... Good...]]  Oh, there are scores of us here.  [Can't you hear them?] We have an  extra train, it leaves at 11.3 o....  Yes, we are under guard, Clive! May  I still call you Clive, now you are  a General?...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cut the cackle. What have you to say  for yourself?]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (He listens and laughs) Listen! I am sorry! [I'm terribly  sorry.] That is what I wanted to  tell you. About our meeting at the  Camp. I was a silly fool. [I had to  tell you before I left.] And now I  must ring off... SEQUENCE 8l Interior: 33 Cadogan Place

dialogues.speaker: HALL
dialogues.text: CLIVE, at the other end of the wire, glances at the clock

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: [[Wait a minute! Don't hang up!   It's only a quarter past nine, now,  I want to see you... Who says I can't?  I've got the G.S.O.I. in charge of  all military transport here to dinner,  as well as your Camp Commander.]]  [Major Davies. Come here a minute,  will you?] (To THEO) I'll send you back to Derbyshire if  you're not careful! - Now you just  sit tight and we'll come and get  you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, all right, I won't run  away.]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've got to come and have a glass  of port! You can't leave England  without having a glass of my port.  Where did you learn that perfect  English of yours?]]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Victoria Station

dialogues.speaker: FIRST CLASS REFRESHMENT ROOM
dialogues.text: THEO is overwhelmed by CLIVE'S open delight and flood of  talk. He answers his last question.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where do you think I learnt it? I  had plenty of time ...  Well, all  right. I shall not run away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He glances through the smoke and over the heads at the cl The time is 9.15.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The clock. The time is 9.25. .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Victoria Station

dialogues.speaker: FIRST CLASS REFRESHMENT ROOM
dialogues.text: A SENTRY is standing on guard at the door, to keep people away. On the door is a sign, such as: 'O.H.M.S.' The SENTRY sees someone approaching across the station. H springs to attention, shoulders arms, salutes. It is MAJOR DAVIES, MAJOR-GENERAL BLOMFIELD and BRIGADIER GENERAL CANDY who are bearing down on him, all smoking ci and all unmistakable senior officers, although in dinner- jackets (except MAJOR DAVIES).

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lieutenant Cartwright inside?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ask him to step outside, sentry!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The SENTRY smartly grounds arms, turns, goes and opens th door. We see a glimpse of the crowded room, thick with sm

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Calls) Lieutenant Cartwright, sir!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sees him coming, returns to his post, snaps to attenti reports:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's coming, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Testily) At ease, man, at ease!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The SENTRY stands at ease.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry to have dragged you out like  this, Piggy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From an excellent glass of port,  too!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LIEUTENANT CARTWRIGHT appears. He is quite shaken by the  senior officers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, Cartwright - this is Major-General  Blomfield - Brigadier-General Candy - (They shake hands.) We want one of your prisoners,  Cartwright. Oberst Kretschmar- Schuldorff is an old friend of the  Brigadier's.  Where's Smollett?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Went to get some dinner, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Call the Oberst out. I'll be  responsible. You can have me and the  Major as hostages.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That will be all right, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He vanishes into the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now look here - I can't leave you  two.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry - you can't finish the  port by 11.30.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door is opened by CARTWRIGHT and THEO appears, a doub smile on his face. He carries his suitcase and greatcoat. CLIVE goes to him and this time THEO doesn't turn away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Interior: Taxi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: [[They are travelling through brightly-lit London streets CLIVE sits opposite THEO to see him better. [They are sit side by side. Both are friendly, but THEO is more reserve

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: [[Theo!]] You Prussian stiff-neck!  The only way is to kidnap you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Gesture) What can I do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Introducing) OberstKretschmar-Schuldorff-Major-  General Blomfield - Major Davies,  you know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Smiles) Intimately.]]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Examining him) [Now, let's have a look at you.]  You've worn well, old chap. Still  got my mark on you, I see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He touches the old scar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you still need a moustache!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, if you two are going -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Going where?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Home. Come on! I've a taxi waiting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When were you captured?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: July '16. [[Nearly three years in  prison.]]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were lucky. You missed the worst  of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: [[Nevertheless]] I would prefer to  have been unlucky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: [That's what you think.] (Changing subject.) Have you heard from home?  Have you  any children? How is Edith?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which shall I answer first?  Edith  is [[well]] [all right], as far as I  can tell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He passes across one of a bundle of [[Red Cross postcards [photographs] he has in his pocket. CLIVE looks at them. [[INSERT: typical Red Cross postcard from Germany filled and signed by Edith in German.])

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boys, eh? Now that one's exactly  like Edith.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Karl?  Yes, he is, isn't he?] [[We  have]] [I almost wish we had] no  children. [[It's better we haven't.]]  What future can children have in a  beaten country?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Tolerantly) [Oh] You Germans are all a bit  [[mad.]] [crazy. You wait till you  meet] Barbara [[will]] [ - she'll]  tell you what's what.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's Barbara?]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: [[Did I tell you I was married? By  the way, old man, you're going to  get a bit of a shock when you see  Barbara - ]] [My wife. Oh, of course,  you don't know I'm married. You'll  get a bit of a shock when you see  her.]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Politely puzzled) [Shock?] I am sure she is charming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Chuckles) [[She's more than that!  You'll see!   She's out now - taken her mother to  the theatre. But she'll be back in  time.]] [I don't mean that. You wait  and see. Of course, you won't see  her. She's gone out to the theatre  with her mother. Never mind.]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The taxi stops outside the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exterior: 33 Cadogan Place

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They get out, THEO clinging to his bag and coat. MURDOCH  appears. THEO looks up at the house as CLIVE pays the tax

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very respectable, your house! Your  streets and houses have so much  dignity - but even more draughts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Wresting his bag and  coat politely but  firmly from him) Good evening, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're right about the draughts, my  boy. That's what blows us English  out of our houses and all over the  world - eh? - he? (Roars with laughter.) I must tell that to Barbara!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They go in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Interior: 33 Cadogan Place

dialogues.speaker: HALL
dialogues.text: They enter. THEO looks round.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: D'you like it?  It was left me by my  Aunt. Murdoch: leave the Oberst's  things there and have a taxi at  eleven. Come on, Theo!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Won't that be too late?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now leave everything to me. I want  you to meet some of the men you've  been fighting with!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They vanish into the dining room.]]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Interior: 33 Cadogan Place

dialogues.speaker: DINING ROOM
dialogues.text: The room is thick with cigar-smoke. Over a dozen gentleme who are sitting around the polished table, rise politely CLIVE comes proudly in with his guest. They wait, without any appearance of curiosity, to be introduced.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gentlemen, this is [my friend] Oberst  Kretschmar-Schuldorff. (There is a murmur of  acknowledgement.) [Sir Archibald Blair, shining light  of the Foreign Office. General  Beveridge...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How d'you do. I've heard about you,  Oberst.]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Major-General Taylor-Grant - General  Keen - Major Michael Cornish and his  brother Major John Cornish -[[Rear]]  Admiral Sir Merton Barrow of the so- called Senior Service - Commodore  Brandon-Crester, ditto - [Major Davies  you know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Intimately.]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: [[Sir Terence Blair, from the Colonial  Office - Lord Clement-Selby,  Lieutenant Governor of Gibraltar]]  [Colonel Hopper, aide to the Governor  of Gibraltar] - Sir William Rendall,  [[First Secretary to the Viceroy]]  [on the Viceroy's staff] - George  Metcalf of Uganda - Sir John  Bembridge, just back from Jamaica - Colonel Mannering, [known to the  press as] the uncrowned king of  Southern Arabia - Mr Christopher  Wynne, of Bradford, England, my father- in-law. [Embodiment of all the solid  virtues.]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like a hailstorm this collection of names, ranks and titl representative of an Empire upon which the sun never sets descends upon THEO. A chair is pulled forward. Everyone s Everyone is anxious to make the German feel at ease.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: [[Drink, Theo?]] [Sit down, Theo.  What will you have to drink?]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Seeing it there) Port [please].

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More than one hand reaches out to pass the decanter round him. As the decanter was only three feet to his left, it to go right round the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It has to go round the clock.]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLIVE pushes boxes towards him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cigar? Cigarette?  [They're both on  the table - thousands of them.]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cigarette, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Turkish! Virginian!]]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't suppose you remember me, but  we met in Berlin in '02.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is the former Second Secretary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, did we?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another guest appears behind them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, Barstow. (To THEO) Colonel Barstow of the Royal Air  Force.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't get up.]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm glad you're on your way home at  last, Oberst.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't imagine anything more awful  than to be a prisoner of war in  England.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think it can be much good  anywhere, General.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: [[But]] [Oh], my dear [[Oberst]]  [fellow], in this country people are  always poking their noses into  everything. Did you get any letters  from spinsters?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Smiles) [[No.]] [Yes, we did.]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: [[Shows you had a sensible Commandant.  Lots of Camps were pestered by them.]]  [I thought so.] They started a  campaign to write to prisoners of  war - not our chaps, mind you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: [[We were spared.]] It was not so  bad - we had books, [[camp-]]concerts,  lectures...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am sure your Camp [[had perfect  administration]] [was well run].  German organization is [[the best in  the world]] [very thorough].

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: [[We nearly had a lot! Ha! Ha!]]  [Bit too thorough for us!]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was the [[food]] [cooking] good?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: [[Quite good.]] [It was English  cooking. (Laughter.])

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A sense of humour!]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My daughter, Joyce, started a campaign  to better the food for German  prisoners in England.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I remember the Government was also  [[accused of]] [charged with] over- feeding them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was taken to one of those Food  Economy meetings during the shortage.  The Ministry of Food speaker asked  her audience point-blank if there  was anyone present who wanted the  prisoners' ration reduced. Nobody  answered.  Then a woman stood up and  said that only when we ourselves  were starving, which was very far  from being the case, should we be  justified in starving prisoners of  war. Then the speaker asked whether,  if any of the audience saw a starving  German prisoner, he would not at  once share his food with him? They  laughed, and then they cheered.]]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, we're not too bad. [Drink up,  gentlemen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Proposes toast) Your health.]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: [[Where did you leave Davies and  Blomfield?]] [What have you done  with old Tiger Blomfield?]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At [Victoria, in the bar of] the  Grosvenor. [[They're]] [He's]  hostage[[s]] [for the Oberst].

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now where is the sense in guarding  officer-prisoners nearly a year after  the fighting is over?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I imagine it is more to [[defend]]  [protect] us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: [[Defend]] [Protect]? Against what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (What people?]])

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your people. They cannot be adjusted  from war to peace as easily as you  [can], gentlemen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you'll find that's not true.]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you [[think]] [mean to say] our  people would attack you in that  uniform?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: [[It is only natural.]] I tried to  Englishmen [in this uniform]. [[I'm  an enemy.]]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: [[Oberst, you're quite wrong.]] [My  dear fellow, that's rather a gloomy  point of view, isn't it?]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've got the wrong end of the stick,  old man. The war's over. There's  nothing to bear malice about. You're  a decent fellow and so are we!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not a decent fellow! I'm a beggar,  like the [[other 800 officers in our  camp]] [rest of all the professional  soldiers in our army]. A beaten  country can't have an army. What are  we going to do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I imagine there'll be a lotto do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But not for us.] We know a [[little]]  [bit] about horses, we can be stable- boys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll feel different when you're  home again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Home! But what will home be like?  Another prison camp?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who says so?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aren't we] [[We are]] going to have  foreign troops occupying our cities  [for years?]. [[You set us prisoners  free but we shan't be free because  our whole country is going to be a  prison camp.]]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've never heard a man more wrong  than you are!  We don't want to make  beggars out of you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are a trading nation, we must  have countries to trade with.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: [[We don't want you out of it. It  simply can't be done.] ] [Surely you  realize that the reconstruction of  Germany is essential to the peace of  Europe?]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: [[And where do you get this idea  that we are going to keep millions  of men under arms to occupy your  country?]] [I can't see our tax-payers  keeping an army in your country. Can  you, Candy?]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course not.] Read the papers,  man! The English papers!  [[I]] [We]  can't ask you to be [[my]] [our]  friend, if [[I]] [we] rob you and  humiliate you first. That's how we  all feel. We want to be friends!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Victoria Station

dialogues.speaker: PLATFORM
dialogues.text: It is 11.27. A special train is at the platform, crowded with German  officers, every window is full of typical faces.  A large crowd has invaded the platform. They are pressing newspap books, magazines, boxes of chocolates on the officers, sh hands and waving. Voices shout: 'Cheerio!' 'Goodbye, Jerry!'  'We don't wan to lose you/But we think you ought to go!'  'Cheer up, Je you couldn't help losing the ruddy war!' THEO and his escort move with difficulty along the train. They have all come to see him off В— the Major-Generals, diplomats, the famous sportsmen ...

dialogues.speaker: PLATFORM
dialogues.text: People give THEO a cheer. They are quick to recognize the type of men who are seeing him off. It looks like an occa Some of the crowd slap him on the back. Complete stranger push packages of cigarettes into his pockets. CLIVE, who has him by the arm, looks proudly at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How is the old German scepticism?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Shakes his head) Fabelhaft! (He has no English  words for it.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some officers hail THEO. He stops at their coach.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here I am!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give my love to Edith!  Tell her -  no, don't tell her anything! Come  and see us sometime in London, or  wherever we are!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A whistle blows. THEO'S luggage is passed in. CLIVE shake him warmly by the hand.  THEO looks out at the smiling fa He shakes his head in amazement.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just like when we went to war...!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The train starts moving. THEO waves. Everyone waves.  CLI is beaming. He turns to the nearest of his friends, which happens to be MAJOR DAVIES.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I think we made an impression  on him!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAJOR DAVIES reserves judgment. .

dialogues.text: Railway Compartment. L.C.& D. Railway

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THEO is speaking to seven of his brother officers who lis with great attention.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: [[Es ist unglaublich!  I have to say  it in English, the German language  has no words for it.]] 'We want to  trade with Germany,' said one!  A  General said: 'We don't want to keep  an army just to occupy your country!'  A General!  They are children] Boys!   playing cricket! They win the shirts  off our backs and now they want to  give them back, because the game is  over!  War is the most unpopular  thing in England!  They are already  organizing pacifist societies, their  newspapers are anti-militarist В—  Here can we get to something! [[This  is our chance!  Their]] [This child- like] stupidity is a raft for us in  a sea of despair!  Do you know what  my friend, [[Brigadier-]]General  Candy said? He said В— [We'll soon  have Germany on her feet again.]

dialogues.text: ([[He breaks off as the door to the corridor slides open the friendly face of LIEUTENANT CARTWRIGHT appears.]] [Cl up of railway lines-trains passing fast.
