dialogues.speaker: CLIVE'S DEN
dialogues.text: CLIVE and BARBARA are having a drink before going to bed. is quite late. She is still in evening dress. He is weari a smoking jacket. CLIVE has just come to the end of the story of the evenin events.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: [[... so I told]] [The last thing I  said to] him: 'My dear old chap,  [don't you worry,] we'll soon have  Germany on her feet again!'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Major Davies would  understand her  expression) And he believed it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Theo? I believe so. I hope so. [[Don't  you?]]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: [[BARBARA stands up. She bends down and kisses him.]] [BA leans back reflectively.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darling, don't hum.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was I humming?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, it's a little habit you've got.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Pauses) What'll I do if I don't hum?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They laugh and hold hands in front of the fire. He kisses her hand. An album of snapshots, Embassy invitations, mementos. INSERT: Times death notice, 'Clive Candy wishes to thank kind friends who have written o sympathize with him in hi irreparable loss.  He hopes to answer them all personally due course' The album's pages are all blank after this.] The camera moves up to the trophies on the wall. [New ones start to appear, dated up to 1938.  A map of  Germany, focusing on Munich.]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INSERT: [[A mimeographed letter, with handwritten dates,  saying roughly the following (wording to be checked): 'Si (or Madam), You are requested under the Enemy Aliens Orde 1920 to appear before Tribunal 132. (In Pelham School, Pe Close, N.W.?.) on Monday Nov. 6th 1939 between 11В—12 a.m Aliens' Registration Book and National Identity Card have be produced.']]  [BCU typewriter typing letter, dated November 1939, summo THEODOR KRETSCHMAR-SCHULDORFF to a Tribunal hearing.]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tribunal

dialogues.speaker: WAITING ROOM
dialogues.text: The Tribunal sits in a requisitioned school. This room wa classroom, but has been transformed into a waiting room. Benches and chairs line the walls. The room is full of  nervous, gloomy people of all ages and sexes, waiting to called.  In the next room, their fates are being decided. The door to it opens and a uniformed policeman comes out  with the papers of two men.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Calls) Mr H. Bruck and Mr S. Bruck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two brothers hold up their hands and answer: 'Here!'  They stand up as the POLICEMAN comes to them and hands ba their books and Identity Cards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can go. S. BRUCK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Turns and calls) Mr Theodor Kretchmar-Shuldorff!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THEO stands up.  He is an old man now, about sixty-five. But he still carries himself like an officer.  He goes in the tribunal.]]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tribunal

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This was also a classroom. It is smaller than the other b there is plenty of room. Behind a desk are seated two men one is the JUDGE, the other an inspector from Scotland Ya (in mufti). Beside the desk sits a middle-aged Englishwom from the Refugee Committee. She also interprets, if neces In a corner, near the door, is a plain wood table, where uniformed policeman sits. He has lists and rubber stamps, comes from the 'Local' Police Station and stamps the pape after the interrogation. The tone of the inquiry is impersonal at first, but later becomes more sympathetic. The JUDGE has the Home Office f of the person interviewed in front of him; it is pretty f documented but he prefers to use it only as a check on th own stories. The inspector does not speak unless asked. THEO enters, comes to his place, clicks his heels togethe (such customs die hard with a German), bows very gently a waits to be questioned.  When he speaks he is unafraid, l a man who has nothing to lose by the truth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr Theodor Kretschmar-Schuldorff?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: [[Yes.]] [Here.]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sit down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your Registration Book and Identity  Card, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He has them in his hand and passes them over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: [Sit down.] When did you arrive in  this country?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the 6th of June [[19]]35.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paris, France. I [[came to]] [arrived  in] Paris on the 15th January 1934.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From Germany?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why did you leave Germany?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My outlook of life is against  [[Nazism]] [the Nazis].

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Most refugees left Germany early in  1933, when Hitler came to power...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had nothing to fear from Hitler.  At least I thought so. It took me  eight months to find out I was wrong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rather a long time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THEO is silent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you think so?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, I mean no offence - but you  in England took five years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The policeman in the corner looks up, but no fire descend from heaven. The JUDGE merely remarks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Drily) Quite right. (Pause.) Have you been in England before?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. I was a prisoner of war in the  last war.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Looking in file) I see you were an officer. When did  you leave the army?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In 1920 В— eight out of ten officers  had to retire when the German Army  ceased to exist В— I mean as a large  army...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You prefer the existence of a large  army?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: [[No]] [Not any more]. In 1920 I  chose a new profession В— Military  Chemist В— I worked for thirteen years  in a factory at Mannheim.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you married?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My wife is dead. ([[Pause.) In 1933.]]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Children?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two. I have no connection with them.  They are good Nazis - as far as any  Nazi can be called good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THEO'S frankness has made an impression on the JUDGE; but at the same time, he has decided to intern him. The  presentation of the facts has been too unvarnished. THEO, course, senses this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: [[Well,]] I'm afraid, Mr Kretschmar- Schuldorff, that doesn't sound very  much in your favour.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Wryly) I have tried to answer correctly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Sympathetically) [[No doubt, but-]] [Personally, I  don't doubt your good faith. But I  am here to safeguard my country's  interests. You may be an anti-Nazi.  You may not be. In times like these,  one enemy in our midst can do more  harm then ten across the Channel. If  you were here to work for the enemy,  what would you tell me now?  Exactly  the same - and that our enemy was  your enemy. I know this is hard on  those who are really with us. But it  should be their best assurance that  this time we mean business. If you  are a friend, our precautions are  your precautions and our interests  are your interests.  Because our  victory will be your victory.] Is  there anything you would like to  add?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Sees that the JUDGE  wants to help him) If you won't mind, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go ahead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Since I have lived in foreign  countries, I am very cautious.]] In  earlier years the most important  principle of my life used to be:  Never lie, always speak the truth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: [[An excellent]] [A very good]  principle. I hope you still keep to  it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have not told a lie. But I also  have not told the truth. A refugee  soon learns that there is a great  difference between the two.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pauses. The JUDGE nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The truth about me is that I am a  tired old man who [[has come]] [came]  to this country because he is  homesick. (He smiles.) Don't stare at me, sir, I am all  right in the head. You [[see]] [know  that], after the war, we had very  bad years in Germany. We got poorer  and poorer. Every day retired officers  or schoolteachers were caught  shoplifting. Money lost its value,  the price of everything rose except  of human beings. We read in the  newspapers that the after-war years  were bad everywhere, that crime was  increasing and that honest citizens  were having a hard job to put the  gangsters in jail [[where they  belonged]]. Well, [I need hardly  tell you that] in Germany, the  gangsters [[started to put]] [finally  succeeded in putting] the honest  citizens in jail. [[Do you know,  sir, who were the first pillars of  the Nazi Party? The dirt of the  people, the lazy ones, the drunkards,  the scum of the country. Ask, sir,  all these people who come here before  you. They will remember them. In  every business there was one who had  no talent and no desire to work or  to learn; and one morning he appeared  with a brown shirt on and a revolver  in his holster. Then they were joined  by the huge army of easy-going people  who always say: 'I am an engineer  and I understand engines: that's  enough forme!']] My wife was English.  She would have loved to [[return]]  [come back] to England, but it seemed  to me that I would have been letting  down my country in its greatest need,  and [so] she stayed at my side. [[When  at last she would have come]] [When  in summer '33, we found that we had  lost both our children to the Nazi  Party, and I was willing to come],  she died. Neither of my sons came to  her funeral [Heil Hitler]... and  then in January [[1934]] [1935],!   [[came up alone]] [had to go] to  Berlin on a mission for my firm. I  drove up in my car. I lost my way on  the outskirts of the city, and  suddenly [[I recognized] I the  landscape [seemed familiar to me.  Slowly I recognized] the road, the  lake and a nursing home, where I  spent some weeks recovering [[many]]  [almost forty] years ago. I stopped  the car and sat still remembering.  [You see, sir,] in this very nursing  home, I met my wife for the first  time ... and I met an Englishman who  became my [[best]] [greatest] friend  [[all those years, although we have  only met twice since then В— in 1919]].  [And I remembered] the people at the  station [in '19], when we [prisoners]  were sent home, cheering us, [treating  us like friends] ... and the faces  [[round a polished table]] of a party  of distinguished men who were kind  and [[did their best]] [tried their  utmost] to comfort me when the defeat  of my country seemed to me  unbearable... And very foolishly I  remembered the [[English]]  countryside, [the gardens,] the green lawns [[where I spe

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence in the schoolroom after THEO'S long speech. The J rises and walks round the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haven't you got anyone in this country  who knows you well, a British citizen?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The doorman at the chemical works  where I offered my services. The  police officers at the Aliens  Department at Bow Street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (To policeman) Sentry! (To THEO) Don't you know Major-General Clive  Wynne-Candy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I used to know him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you ask him to come here and  testify on your behalf?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I did send him a letter, but I  suppose he...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door opens and CLIVE appears.  [[During his last words a disturbance has started outside and has gradually grown in intensity, doors are slamming, voices are raised and, as everyone looks around at the do it bursts open and, flanked by awed policemen, MAJOR-GENE WYNNE-CANDY enters the room]]. He is, of course, three years younger than when we met hi in the Turkish Bath at the beginning of our story, but he physically much the same and he is much more self-assured and pompous now, before the disappointments of the next t years have deflated him. He talks very loudly and goes  straight to the JUDGE as the only person worthy of his  attention, beside THEO.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By gad, sir, Lord Prendergast was  right!  He told me I'd never find  this blasted school!  My card, sir!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He flings his card down on the table. INSERT: visiting card. 'Major-General Clive Wynne-Candy,  V.C., D.S.O. 33 Cadogan Place, s.w.i. Boodles Club.']]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLIVE has grabbed THEO, pleased and bewildered[[, turned to the light and slaps him on the back]].

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: [Theo, my dear chap,] Let me have a  good look at you, [[old bean - my  old German bean - eh? - dashed good!]] (Roars with laughter.) By gad, you've kept your figure better  than I have! (He slaps his tummy.) Bit of a bay window, eh? [[But there's  life in the old dog yet! (He turns to the JUDGE.) Sorry, sir, to butt into your court- martial, unpardonable intrusion and  all that sort of thing, but I only  got down from the North yesterday  and I'm off to France - well, mustn't  say when, but damn soon!  В— Found  this idiot's letter waiting for me,  put Sherlock Holmes on his track,  got his address - (To THEO) Don't think much of your choice in  digs, old chap - they said you had  to come here В— the war, I suppose -  so I dropped Buggy Prendergast at  the Club - he'd had enough - and  came along myself to take you home  with me - (To JUDGE) If it's all right with you, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLIVE obviously takes it for granted that it is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm afraid, Clive, that I can't come  with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are going to intern me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Explodes) Pooh! Ridiculous!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns on the poor JUDGE, who starts to assert himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My dear General, the law is the law.  This is a civil court and you have  already disturbed it. I have the  greatest respect for your -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (With great charm) Gad, sir, I'm awfully sorry. I come  bursting in like a bull in a china  shop! You're absolutely right, sir,  you're absolutely right! I apologize!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He extends his hand, the JUDGE has to take it. CLIVE shak it vigorously and points to THEO, who is looking admiring at his friend's easy authority.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know him well, sir, and I'd go  bail for him anywhere.  You can have  all the credentials you want. I know  everybody in London who is anybody!  Is this a Home Office or a Foreign  Office do? Can I use your telephone?  Hullo! Hullo! Operator! (Jerking at THEO.) He's just exactly the opposite of  the men we ought to be interning!   Hullo!  Operator!]] [You see, sir, I  wouldn't be surprised if this fellow  really dislikes us. He comes to  England twice in his life: the first  time he's a prisoner and the second  time he's about to be one.  May I  talk to him, sir? I haven't seen him  for nineteen... er...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twenty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twenty years and a bit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Afraid not here, General. We have  many Kretschmar-Schuldorffs waiting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean to say that I've travelled  eleven miles from В— mustn't say where -  and you won't allow me to have a  word with a condemned man?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you don't have to go back this  minute, do you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tomorrow morning, sir, and infernally  early too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you can talk to him all day  and all night till midnight В— Aliens'  Curfew, you know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And can I take him with me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you say you know him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do I know him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And will stand surety for him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With everything I have, sir.]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Interior: 33 Cadogan Place

dialogues.speaker: DINING ROOM
dialogues.text: CLIVE and THEO are sitting on after dinner, smoking in  companionable silence. There is an enormous difference be the two men. For CLIVE very little has changed; for THEO  everything: he has seen less than CLIVE during the years he has experienced more. He is a wise man now. He speaks  with a little smile about the most important things. His  attitude is that of a man very little concerned with life troubles. He has nothing to lose because he has lost  everything. Outside it is quite late. It is winter. The windows are  shuttered. [[After a moment THEO looks at his watch.]] [Clock chimes

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's time I was going. [[I must be  home by midnight.]]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: [[Why midnight?]] [The night is young  yet.]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: [Don't you remember?] Curfew for  aliens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Blimpish nod) Ah-yes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to be home by midnight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MURDOCH comes in. He is about the same age as his master has become, over the years, the perfect butler.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't forget, sir. You have to be up  for 6.30.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Early parade, eh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How lucky you are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, they put me on the retired list  in '35. But I knew they'd want me  again. Back I went on the active  list like a shot. (Changes the subject.]) I mean, why don't you stay here?  I've eighteen rooms. (Bellows.) Murdoch!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks, Clive, but I don't think I  had better. I would need a special  permit anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MURDOCH comes in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You called, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, Murdoch, it was nothingВ—no!   [[As you were!]] (To THEO) Stay a little longer, I'll send you  back by car. Murdoch, tell Miss Cannon  to be here at quarter to twelve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He goes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's Miss Cannon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: [[Johnny]] [Miss] Cannon, my driver.  [[A.T.S.]] [M.T.C.]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: [Do you] Remember, Clive, we used to  say: 'Our army is fighting for our  homes, our women and our children'?   Now the women are fighting beside  the men. [[In Germany,]] the children  are trained to shoot. [[Only remains]]  [What's left is]: the 'home'. But  what is 'home' without women and  children?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Nods, then says  suddenly) You never met my wife. Do you want  to see [a picture of] her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very much... (They both laugh as  they stand up.) ... do you remember when that was  all I could say in English?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got further with it [then] than  I ever got.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In what respect?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My dear fellow, don't tell me you  [[never knew]] [didn't know]...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: [[That I - dash it, don't]] [you]  make me blush!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I don't know what you are talking  about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well - I thought it was written all  over my face when I left Berlin in  [[19]]02.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't forget, I never saw [[you]]  [your face] after you left.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (It is a great secret) I was in love with [her - ] your  wife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Slowly) She never told me...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She never knew.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But [[when I told you]] [I seem to  remember] - that last day [in Berlin] -  [[that I loved her]] - you seemed  genuinely happy...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dash it - I didn't know then. But on  the train I started to miss her - it  was worse on the boat - and by the  time I was back in London -well, I'd  got it properly. My Aunt Margaret  got on the scent [[right]] [straight]  away, women have a nose for these  things. Besides I did a stupid thing!   First night back I took out her  sister...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aunt Margaret's?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edith's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (More puzzled) Martha?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Martha.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But what was stupid about that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Gruffly) Thinking her sister would be like  she was.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: [Like] Edith?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLIVE nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Tenderly) [[Anyway]] [Well], you got over it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's just it, I [[didn't]] [never  did get over it]. Theo, this may  sound a damn silly thing to say to  you but I never got over it. [[I  suppose you could]] [You may] say  she was my ideal - if you were some  [sort of] sickening long-haired poet  В— all my life I've been looking for  a girl like herВ—so now you know В—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Quite thunderstruck) I never thought it possible that an  Englishman could be so romantic... (Pause.) And your wife you don't mind my  asking? You loved her...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes... dreadfully. She was exactly  like Edith. I'll show her to you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes THEO'S arm and leads him out of the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Interior: 33 Cadogan Place

dialogues.speaker: CLIVE'S DEN
dialogues.text: The walls are completely crowded with trophies except in spot which, until now, we have not seen. A painting hangs there, covered by a curtain. CLIVE pulls a cord and the curtain slides aside. It is a  painting of Barbara at the time of her marriage and very  much like her.  THEO looks at the painting for quite a li time before he speaks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Quietly) She's very lovely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isn't she like Edith? Eh? See the  resemblance?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now actually it is quite hard for THEO to see any resembl at all. CLIVE'S memory of Edith is different from THEO'S. She has always stayed young to him as he last saw her. TH continues to stare at the picture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Answering CLIVE) Yes... there is something very  striking... But you mustn't forget,  I saw Edith thirty-one years later  than you. We grew old together - you  understand?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Blimpish agreement) Hm! -yesВ— [[suppose so]] [of course]  В— but she was [[very]] [exactly]  like her -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Looking round) It's a strange place to hang such a  lovely picture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She wanted it. I call this my Den,  you know. She knew I always used to  come back here, we had a joke about  it - all my stuff is here. It would  be an awful gap without her ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: [[He pulls the curtain back over the painting.]] Goes to side-table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have a peg - what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Looks at his back) It must be terrible to lose someone  very dear to you in a foreign country.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Pouring out drinks) It wasn't a foreign country. It was  Jamaica.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exterior: 33 Cadogan Place

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLIVE stands in the half-open door, a bright light stream from the hall. THEO is beside him in an overcoat of obvio Continental cut. MURDOCH stands half-way with a torch.  The car, JOHNNY CA at the wheel, is waiting. CLIVE shakes hands warmly with THEO.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: [[God bless you. Come back safely,  Clive.]] [Bye, Clive.  Have a nice  journey.]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: [[Nothing to worry about!]] [Don't  worry about anything.] Everything  under control.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope it is as you say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He goes to the car.]]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you close the door, sir, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, shut up, Murdoch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: [[But he closes it all the same and looks around.]] THEO gets in beside the driver. He opens the window as MU fusses around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good luck, Murdoch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, sir, but the General isn't  taking me. I stay [[here and do  A.R.P.]] [to look after things here.]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Bellows) You know the way, [[Miss Cannon]]  [Angela]?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (As the car moves) Good hunting. There's just room in  the Den for Hitler's moustache!]]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door, sir, please.]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you see the Warden?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am the Warden of this District,  sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Interior: General's Car

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOHNNY CANNON seems to be a very efficient, matter-of-fac girl, judging by her voice. Neither can see the other in black-out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't mind my sitting beside  you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, sir.]]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It must be difficult driving in the  black-out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: [[It looks more than it is.]] [It's  not as bad as it looks, sir.]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After a pause THEO goes on talking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I suppose you've done a lot of night- driving?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, sir. (She realizes she  must explain this.) I never drove before the war.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What made you learn?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My boy-friend taught me. But not at  night. ([[She laughs.]])

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is he a good driver?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First-rate. He's one of the Bentley  boys. [[But]] just now he walks [on  his two flat feet]. He's a private.  In training.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What was your job before the war,  Miss Cannon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Photographic model.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Interesting work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: [[It was all right]] [Not bad]. A  bit hard on the feet.  How did you  know my name, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: [[I heard]] the General [told me  about you].

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, [[of course.]] [Did he? Mind if  we try to beat the lights, sir? (Brakes sharply.) Sorry, sir, couldn't make it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you like being [[his]] [the  General's] driver?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who wouldn't?  He's an old darling.  I could have done a hand-stand when  he chose me. [[It was at an  inspection.]] [D'you know] He picked  me out of seven hundred girls to be  his driver.  Some odds [[700 to 1]]  [wasn't it?]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A car is approaching with a badly fitted mask, the light  points higher than it should.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at that headlight. He ought to  be reported.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The headlight flashes for a moment on her face. Only for moment. THEO stares, startled, at the girl by his side. knows now why the General chose her out of seven hundred  girls. It is the same face. Edith В— Barbara В— and now this girl. The other car has passed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Grumbles) That's what causes accidents. (To THEO) Long odds, weren't they, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (In a reverie) I beg your pardon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seven hundred to one! Makes me a bit  of an outsider. (She chuckles.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is your first name, Miss Cannon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Angela.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lovely name. It comes from 'angel'  [doesn't it?].

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think it stinks. My friends call  me 'Johnny'. (She peers out.) Is it this crossing or the next  [,sir]?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: [[I'll get out here]] [Oh, this will  do]. [[Many thanks.]]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He opens the door and gets out. They have stopped by a tr light. THEO holds out his hand. She shakes it firmly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodnight, Angela.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodnight, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd like to see your boy-friend one  of these days.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me too! [Goodnight, sir.]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She laughs.  THEO vanishes into the darkness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: British Broadcasting Corporation

dialogues.speaker: FADE IN
dialogues.text: Insert: the usual contract form of the British Broadcasti Corporation. The details: 'Major-General Clive Wynne-Cand V.C., D.S.O., will give the Sunday night Postscript on Ju 16 1940. Title: Dunkirk В—Before and After'.

dialogues.speaker: A DIRECTOR'S OFFICE
dialogues.text: The contract (or a copy) is lying on the desk of one of t Directors of the B.B.C. [[Beside the contract is a telephone, which is buzzing  discreetly. Behind the desk sits]] the DIRECTOR [sits on low chair, nervously]. He is a charming diplomatic man, d his best in a very awkward and responsible job. He is abo forty-five. [With him is a SECRETARY.] The office is underground. The light is crude and glaring [The telephone buzzes.]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: [The SECRETARY answers it.]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: General Wynne-Candy has just passed  through the entrance hall, sir.]]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's on his way down now.]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: [[Thank you.]] [For the love of  Gielgud, go and stop him as he gets  out of the lift. If you let him put  one whisker inside the studio, you  are out!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Echoes) ... out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: British Broadcasting Corporation

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: UNDERGROUND CORRIDOR Crude functional architecture. Crude glaring lighting. An impression of great depth and streng Many people are bustling to and fro with papers. The lift has just arrived down. CLIVE comes out with several other He looks tired and worn, but otherwise all right. He glan at the ultra-modern clock on the wall. It shows 20.45. CL is accompanied by a GUIDE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This way, [[sir]] [General].

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But a girl who has been waiting at the lift now steps for She is the DIRECTOR'S SECRETARY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: General Wynne-Candy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Turns a terrifying  eye on her) [[Mm!  - ]] [Yes.]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This way to Studio 5, sir.]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr Herbert Marsh would like to see  you, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never heard of him!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: [[One of the directors.]] [Yes, but  he's heard of you sir.]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: [[Mm! - Mm - Ah, yes!]] [Oh, has he?   Good. (Following her.])

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: [It's] This way [to Studio 5], sir. ([Pointing in opposite  direction.])

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lead on!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They start walking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When does my [[ - ah!]] broadcast  start precisely?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well almost at once, sir.]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: [[The Postscript, sir?  About]] [At]  21.20. [, sir].

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: [[Lots]] [Plenty] of time [[-good- ]]!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me, miss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, shut up. (Steering CLIVE.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Regular rabbit warren, eh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. (Hurrying him.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beehive of industry. D'you like  working here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, very much. You meet such  interesting people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can tell that from the  programmes.]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They arrive at a door: 'H. Marsh, Acting Director'.  With knocking, the GIRL opens the door. [SECRETARY opening door to MARSH'S office General Wynne- Candy.] CLIVE walks innocently in. She closes it with relief behi him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: British Broadcasting Corporation

dialogues.speaker: A DIRECTOR'S OFFICE
dialogues.text: MR MARSH is prepared to be very friendly. He stands up. C comes in speaking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think I've met you, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: [[I have never had the]] [No, I'm  afraid I've not had that] pleasure.  Won't you sit down?  Cigarette?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Accepting) Very snug quarters here. And deep!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Smiles) We need to be these days.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quite agree!  Back to the Stone Age,  what? (He puts down his  cigarette.) Think I'll leave this, if you don't  mind. Bad for speaking. Makes my  throat dry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: [[There may be some difficulty]]  [General, I'm afraid we've been having  a bit of trouble] about your broadcast  [[,General...]].

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: [[Can't be worse than Dunkirk.]]  [Well, I'm used to trouble. I'm a  soldier.]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: [[We have been advised at the last  moment that your broadcast is  considered]] [Yes, the - um -  authorities think it's a little] ill- timed and [[must be]] [that it might  be better] postponed ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Stares, goes purple) [[Considered? Considered? Who is  considering? Why?]] ['Think it's a  little ill-timed.' Who has been saying  that? Why?]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: [[I'm afraid]] [Well], General, [you  know] that in time of war [[it is]]  В—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't talk to me about war! (He stands up.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Quietly) No. [Of course,] That would be - ([Pauses]) Grotesque.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have been asked to describe in  this broadcast my views of the cause  of the Retreat and its aspects for  the future. There they are!  I have  been serving my country for forty- four years. What was your position  before this one, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (murmurs) Lawyer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? A lawyer!  Well, I was a  soldier. And before that, I suppose  you were at college. And I was a  soldier. And I was a soldier when  you were a baby, and before you were  born, sir, when you were nothing but  a toss-up between a girl's and a  boy's name - I was a soldier then! (He suddenly stops,  collects himself,  stares at Mr Marsh.) I'm deeply sorry, sir. I know it's  not you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Who has listened  patiently) No. I'm afraid [[not]] [it isn't].

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will make the necessary enquiries  through the War Office. I'll have a  light for this cigarette now, if you  please.  [[Thanks. Pity I sent my  car away.]]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Interior: 33 Cadogan Place

dialogues.speaker: DINING ROOM
dialogues.text: THEO and JOHNNY CANNON are listening to the radio. (June was the day Petain came to power.) MURDOCH is making the  black-out. The table is laid for two people with a cold  supper.  The News finishes. There is a pause.   ANNOUNCER: (Rustling paper) [That brings us to the end of the news and] Tonight's Postscript [which] is given by Mr B.  Priestley. Mr Priestley ... MURDOCH turns sharply. The others react. THEO is not  surprised.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What can have happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was expecting it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've read his speech.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We hear the front door bang. Meanwhile the radio is silen

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The General!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The GENERAL'S return is a great surprise. JOHNNY leaps to her feet. She has no business to be here. She looks wildl around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (On radio) [[We apologize to listeners for]]  [Sorry about] the short delay. Here  is Mr Priestley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Without a qualm, MURDOCH turns Mr Priestley off before he has said a word.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Murdoch! Where can I go? The General  mustn't find me here! Murdoch!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me handle it, Angela...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No fear. Let me out of here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The GENERAL comes in. He is not angry; only disappointed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hullo, Theo. If supper's ready, you  can serve it, Murdoch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm very sorry, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hm? Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I shouldn't be here - I -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I asked Miss Cannon to come in. She  was anxious to hear your broadcast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cancelled! At the last minute. Pity  we hurried like we did, Angela. (To THEO) We didn't leave the War Office until  [[twenty-five]] [five and twenty] to  nine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a War Office letter here,  sir. It came this afternoon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (CLIVE holds out his hand. MURDOCH gives him the letter. op ens it.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul Reynaud [has] resigned. Petain  is Prime Minister.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bad news.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? (He has started reading  the letter.) Oh, yes - bad news.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MURDOCH: Sherry, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Looking up) Ah - yes! (Goes on reading.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: [[(MURDOCH pours out drinks, looks enquiringly at JOHNNY. She shakes her head. He pours one for THEO, puts down the decanter and goes out. THEO picks up the decanter and pou a drink for ANGELA. She doesn't think it proper to drink  with the GENERAL and shakes her head violently. THEO  smiles.}}]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sherry, miss?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (She grimaces to dissuade him. To THEO)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sherry, Mr -, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes please.] (In a low voice) How is your fiance?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Same tone) He's not my fiance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: [Beg your pardon. How is] Your boy- friend?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's getting a commission.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Congratulations.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: [[I think]] I ought to go [you know].

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks towards CLIVE. He is still reading. He turns ba to the first page and starts re-reading the whole thing.  THEO and JOHNNY continue to talk in low tones.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Nod towards CLIVE) [[Wait a little longer.]] [No, stay  a bit.]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: [[O.K.]] [Down the hatch. (Pause.) Any news about your application ?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Turned down. Enemy alien.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you're an expert!  Why didn't  you ask him. He knows everybody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was [[in France]] [away].

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MURDOCH brings some soup and bottled beer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dinner is served, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLIVE mechanically folds the letter. He is only half  listening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah-yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Stands up) I'm going now, sir. Will you [[need]]  [want] the car [any more]?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've brought another cover, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Absently) All right. Sit down, Angela. Theo!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They glance at one another.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sit down, both of you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never mind, Murdoch. (To CLIVE) Thank you, sir, but I had dinner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have another, Angela.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, really - I -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (In a normal voice at  last) If you're worried about sitting down  with your General, then stop worrying.  I'm not a General any more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (He knows better than  anyone what tragedy  this means for his  friend) Clive! What has happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Retired [again]. Axed!  They don't  need me any more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, sir. (Passing the sherry  glass to CLIVE.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ([[Holds out his hand  to seize his  friend's]]) I know how that feels.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No you don't!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was barely forty-five when it  happened to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Different kettle offish!  [[Your  country was]] [You were] made to do  it. [But] We're not finished - nor  am I! Just starting! (Bites moustache.) - I've often thought - somebody like  me dies - special knowledge - awful  waste В— Well, am I dead? Is my  knowledge worth nothing?  Skill  experience В— eh? You tell me -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a different knowledge they need  now, Clive. The enemy is different.  [[The defenders must be]] [So you  have to be] different too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: [[Have you gone]] [Are you] mad? I  know what war is!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't agree. I read your broadcast  up to the point where you describe  the collapse of [[your own sector  in]] France. You commented on Nazi  methods, foul fighting, bombing  refugees, machine-gunning hospitals,  lifeboats, lightships, baled-out  pilots, by saying that you despised  them, that you would be ashamed to  fight on their side and that you  would sooner accept defeat than  victory if it could only be won by  those methods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So I would!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clive!  If you let yourself be  defeated by them, [just because you  are too fair to hit back the same  way they hit at you,] there won't be  any methods but Nazi methods! If you  preach the Rules of the Game while  they use every foul and filthy trick  against you, they will laugh at you!   They think you're weak, decadent! I  thought so myself in 1919.  [[Filthiness! That is their secret  weapon!]]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (A little shaken) I[['ve]] heard all that in the last  war. They played foul then. And who  won it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think you won it! We lost  it!  But you lost something, too.  You forgot to learn the moral.  [[Because victory was yours]] you  failed to learn your lesson twenty  years ago, you have to pay the school  fees again! Some of you will learn  quicker than others. Some will never  learn it. [Because] You have been  educated to be a gentleman and a  sportsman - in peace and in war.  But, Clive, [[my dear fellow]] [dear  old Clive], this is not a gentleman's  war. [[This is a life and death  struggle, with your backs to your  cliffs against the hordes of  barbarism.]] [This time you are  fighting for your very existence  against the most devilish idea ever  created by a human brain В— Nazism.]  And if you lose there won't be a  return match next year, perhaps not  even for a hundred years! (He pats CLIVE'S  [[hand]] [shoulder].) You mustn't mind me, an alien, saying  all this. But who can describe  hydrophobia better than one who has  been bitten - and is now immune?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (He is defeated. He  knows Theo is right  but cannot say so) Well, you see, Angela - eh?  Even  one's best friend lets one down...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOHNNY has been the silent witness of the scene. She is t young to be detached. Her respect for the GENERAL makes i quite painful for her to listen. She, of course, agrees  entirely with THEO. She does not know where to look until directly appealed to by CLIVE. She looks miserably up at and af THEO.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think so, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Grunts) You, too, eh? Kick a fellow when  he's down - what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Weak smile) Nobody would ever kick you, sir.   [[You'll have]] [You've just got] to  change over, that's all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Change over? To what? (He already speaks in  a stronger voice.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well - [[some other]] [a new] job  [[,sir]]. It's easy enough for a  man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hm! Think so, do you? Swop horses in  midstream - eh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Daring) A lot of people had to in this war,  sir. It's better than drowning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bravo, Angela! I shall call you Johnny  in future!  She's hit the nail on  the head! I don't know you. You  shouldn't give up so easily, my boy.  Is this the same man who took Berlin  by storm forty years ago? Look at  me! Nobody wants me but do I give  up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Depressed again) Nobody wants you - and you're an  expert. I don't know anything but  soldiering - (Looks at letter.) В— not even that, apparently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about the Home Guard, sir?   They [[must have]][need] leaders.  They are just becoming an army. If  we are invaded, they're] [[will be]]  our first [[line of]] defence -  [[all]] the papers say so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There you are! You know everybody,  you could get them arms and  instructors and equipment! [[I wish  I could join.]] What a grand job,  forming a new army.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Looks from one to  the other with great  suspicion) EH? - HOME GUARD-?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Entering) Yes, sir. I was going to tell you  myself, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks reproach fully at JOHNNY and puts down some chee and the Cona. CLIVE gapes at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're drunk, Murdoch. Tell me what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That I'd joined the Home Guard, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. (He is about to clear  away when he realizes  no food has been  touched.) Anything wrong with the soup, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (With gathering  momentum) How should anyone know if nobody's  touched it. Take it away, [[Private]]  [Lance- Corporal] Murdoch!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Proudly) Sergeant Murdoch, sir. (Gathering up cold  soup.) What have you been doing, sir, all  this time?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Seizing carving knife  and steel, sharpens  it) Nothing, you blockhead, except talk! (Seizing carving fork.) But watch now!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He starts a murderous assault on the cold chicken.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: [Explosion and star-burst on screen.]

dialogues.speaker: FADE IN
dialogues.text: INSERT:'In Memoriam' column in The Times. 'MURDOCH В— In and loving memory of John Montgomery Murdoch, my friend a comrade in two great wars, killed by enemy action in an a raid of [[April 20]] [Oct.] 1941.  Clive Wynne-Candy.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exterior: 33 Cadogan Place

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The house we know so well has received a direct hit and l in ruins, although those on either side are hardly touche The Demolition Squad are working on the ruins, amongst cl of dust. One of them pulls out a frightening object, coated with d from the rubbish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: [[Crikey!  This is a bit of all  right!]] [Hello! What's this?]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He shakes and bangs the hairy object which gradually reve itself as the pride of Clive's Den: 'Buffalo Head' -  'Nigeria''- '1924'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Upsadaisy! (He has hold of a  long curved thing.) Give us a hand, Marmaduke!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They both pull and, in a cloud of dust and clatter of rub a rhinoceros']] [a boar's] head emerges. Both regard it  solemnly.

dialogues.text: That's all right.
